@Scott Koontz I have read something, quite a few somethings actually. I have researched this subject for the last several years, and have corresponded at length with four climatolgists. CO2 has not been this 'high' for the last 13 million years, but prior to that, it was very much higher for most of the last 600 million years. Some of the increase in CO2 since pre-industrial times is caused by the gradual increase in temperature as we continue to come out of the last ice age, some is caused by human activity. However, both the slight increase in temperature and the increase in CO2 are beneficial not harmful, and this whole 'climate crisis' remains a deliberately-orchestrated deception.

It is man that is polluting BUT the lies about co2 have hidden the damage we are doing with REAL pollution.

As to why we are not the greatest creators of co2? co2 increased from 280 to 410 an increase of 46%. There is evidence that there have been spikes of co2 of up to 350 ppm for as long as a century after some volcano activity. The spike we have is less barely more than half a century. This means we do not even know how much of the increase is man made. Yes it is very likely that the majority of it is man made, but we do not even know that.

BUT the majority of the problem isn't how much co2 has been added, but how SENSITIVE is the atmosphere to co2 change. Evidence is that it is about .5°c or less. No model what has its sensitivity set to less than 2°c will produce a disaster. Anything less than a 1° is pretty much a yawn.

So where is the warming coming from if not from co2? From glacial melt. Yes, you mentioned water on rocks and that is precisely the problem. The sun warms the rocks, and that passes the heat to the ice of glaciers and then increases the temperature to the same temperature of the ocean. The result is that the water absorb a lot of energy that would normally be radiated into space, but is trapped on the earth in the form or liquid water. THAT is the imbalance between the energy the earth receives and loses.

Folks, I understand how you people must be concerned with the perceived danger of Global Warming. I have to tell you some truths and facts about what you are being told. Bearing in mind, that in order to reduce the temperature of the world by limiting or abolishing the production of CO2, is a horrendously expensive task world wide. This attempt in itself, regardless of what the climate is doing, can only lead to disastrous rises in the cost of energy which in turn will lead to economic collapse of world economies along with of course disastrous effects on the world populace. (Yup I majored in economics - class of 1981 - and for me this is easy to see). You see, our economies are based on fossil energy, Coal, Gas and Oil etc and unless equally or less expensive substitutes are found, without these things, most of us will starve and/or freeze to death. But perhaps, as you are no doubt postulating on your site, if we are not going to ruin the planet, maybe the above cost will be worthwhile? So at the very least, trying to cool the planet is a very serious thing to attempt and I am sure that you would agree that we should not go down this road unless we have absolute proof that humans are warming the planet and that the predictions we are hearing from some sources are scientifically confirmed Fortunately there is a scientific method which allows us to decide whether the above is true or not. If you read Karl Popper and if you wish to take it even further, William of Ockham, you can find the basis of the scientific disproof of a hypothesis. This quick video may help. Richard Feynman on disproving a hypothesis https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OL6-x0modwY And Dr Roy Spencer Graph showing Models and empirical measurements. http://www.drroyspencer.com/wp-content/uploads/CMIP5-73-models-vs-obs-20N-20S-MT.png (The accompanying commentary for the above can be found on Dr Spencer's website archive Blogs June 2013) This is a good example of Popper's disproval of a hypothesis. In this case the models are the hypothesis', (or law as Feynman describes them) and the actual temperature measurements, some of which are satellites, represent the empirical measurements. Therefore it is very obvious that the models fall under Feynman's rejection. There is therefore no scientific evidence that the earth is warming, (or cooling), other than what has already been observed throughout history. Unfortunately, governments like excuses to issue new laws. As most governments nowadays, (including that of New Zealand), are sliding steadily to the left, this gives them an excuse to issue more laws and regulations of the sort which we must obey at the cost of trading a little of our freedom and democracy. We see this happening in our society at this very moment as common law is replaced with regulative legislation in most sectors. Common law traditionally is/was at arms length from governments. Regulations by legislation are not. So please take the time to study these things. I understand how difficult it is to give up beliefs that you have accumulated, but one must remain logical and scientific in these things. To be otherwise one must be dishonest with one self. Cheers Roger http://www.rogerfromnewzealand.wordpress.com

Yes, and then ENDING the trend with super-hot years tends to amplify it. In both cases, it was an El Nino that was responsible for he warming, and had nothing to do with 'global warming'. I wonder why they would mention how 1998 was an El Nino year but they FAIL to mention that 2015 was also an El Nino year. I wonder why that is? Boy, that sure is a puzzler. (go ahead, I searched for Nino in the article. The only mention is the 98 El Nino, not the 2015 one)

Hey, and here's another thing I wonder: I wonder why a few months of warmer weather caused by El Nino is something that 'weakens the argument, but 18 years and 8 months of flat temps does NOT weaken the global warming argument, EVEN THOUGH they were all DEAD WRONG about it. Again, another puzzler. 

And now that I'm wondering, I gotta wonder why the article said this:

"Moreover, over the past 18 years that Cruz likes to cite — the period since 1998, a record warm El Nino year that officially remains the hottest year in the satellite record — there’s now also a trend, despite the fact that starting an analysis with this super-hot year tends to mute it"

Actually, they are quoting Cruz from January, and so the latest temp readings that gave us 18 years and 8 months of a pause only go to Sept 2015. This means that 18 years and 8 months was actually the beginning of 1997. 

Why is this important? Well, as you can see from their statement above, they are trying to get us to believe that the RSS data starts from the very hottest point in 1998. But if you look at the 18/8 graph, it actually starts in 1997. And the very first month that is graphed is not only not unusually hot, but's it's actually BELOW NORMAL. 

That's right, instead of cherry-picking an unusually high temp to start (as this article tries to claim), the start date for the 18/8 is actually a below normal temp anomaly. Again, I have to wonder why they did this. 

You see, you have to know how to read articles like this one and you have to know the facts (as I've just presented them), so you can sort through the obvious unscientific bias.

@MultiTacs the quote from Einstein is taken out of context. His full quote was "no amount of experimentation can prove me right, but a single expirement can prove me wrong". He was referring to his theory of relativity, which explains gravity. No amount of people testing and using his formulas could prove him 100 percent right, because all that means is that you've never stumbled upon a case where the equations failed. When he says that one expirement could prove me wrong, what he means is that if one case was found where is equations failed, that represents the failure of his formula, brought on by just one expirement. In the climate case, we're not talking about new laws that explain the way things work, we're talking about getting different results when analyzing the effect of humans on climate change; we're using the same data ideally, but we're coming to different conclusions. In this case, if there is a huge amount of evidence that leans one way, the other interpretations are likely not accurate; thus the concept of a scientific concensus of observation.

The Athabasca Glacier is one of the six principal 'toes' of the Columbia Icefield, located in the Canadian Rockies. The glacier currently recedes at a rate of about 5 metres (16 ft) per year[1]
 and has receded more than 1.5 km (0.93 mi) and lost over half of its 
volume in the past 125 years. The glacier moves down from the icefield 
at a rate of several centimetres per day. Due to its close proximity to 
the Icefields Parkway, between the Alberta towns of Banff and Jasper, and rather easy accessibility, it is the most visited glacier in North America.[2]
 The leading edge of the glacier is within easy walking distance; 
however, travel onto the glacier is not recommended unless properly 
equipped. Hidden crevasses have led to the deaths of unprepared tourists.

+Robusti09 Yes, earth would absolutely be colder without greenhouse gases.  That being said, if you hold to the evolutionary time line, earth has already had a far warmer climate during the dinosaur age.  Far hotter climate - zero human influence.  Then, depending on which expert scientists you side with, the earth had one, or dozens of, ice age(s), followed once again by a warm period(s).  Humans certainly have an influence on greenhouse gases -- I just believe that the influence is more on the scale of swimmers peeing in the ocean.  But my overall argument is that we shouldn't leap to a conclusion just because "scientists" have.  Remember that very recently -- on the scientific timeline -- we were worrying about global cooling and another ice age.  For the record, I think we should always be looking for ways to act responsibly environmentally, socially, morally... but relying on the vagaries of scientists is probably the poorest foundation for doing so.

The sun is getting hotter
There is no single continuous satellite measurement of Total Solar Irradiance (TSI). Instead, the data is composited from various satellite measurements. The two most cited composites are PMOD and ACRIM. According to Nicola Scafetta, ACRIM more faithfully reproduces the observations whereas PMOD assumes the published TSI satellite data are wrong and need additional corrections. In particular, PMOD alters the data from the Nimbus7/ERB record from 1989 to 1991. Nimbus7/ERB data during such a short period show a clear upward trend while PMOD during the same period is almost constant. The alteration of the Nimbus7/ERB data is responsible for the different shape between the ACRIM and PMOD TSI composites (Shining More Light on the Solar Factor).

There are only 4 things you need to know about climate science to shut up a delusional denier:
1) Measurable Fact: Atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (carbon dioxide) and CH4 (methane) have been steadily increasing since the dawn of the industrial revolution.
2) "Radiative forcing" (put simply) is the measure of how much heat energy is produced by an atmospheric gas molecule (CO2 and CH4) when it is struck by a light photon from the sun.
3) Measurable Fact: CO2 and CH4 have the highest "radiative forcing" value of all atmospheric gases.
4) Measurable Fact: The observed increase in global temperature (since the dawn of the industrial revolution) overwhelmingly correlates with and validates #'s 1,2 & 3, because it can't correlate with anything else.

For those who haven't seen it, potholer54's series/playlist "Climate Change Explained, and Myths Debunked" is a must-view. 
And now you have your search terms.   Watch it, you'll be a lot more discerning when reading science news.
It's apolitical, strong on science, and does a fantastic job of explaining both the science behind climate change, and, very importantly, the *presentation* thereof.  
Points out and explains mistakes, misunderstandings, and misinformation.  Takes on both alarmists and deniers, but especially takes on the way they paint the picture.  Monckton fans, grab a tissue.  
Video quality's crap, but that's my only detraction.   Whole playlist is nearly 6 hrs, avg episode about 11 mins.

text: One thing is for sure. Us humans are killing the planet.

You also cannot study climate in terms of the past decade or decades. The public conversation changes from global warming to global cooling and vice versa every 20-30 years as the climate swings. Climate naturally cycles through cold periods and warm periods. In terms of carbon dioxide, the levels scale up proportionally after temperature goes up- not before. There is a lot of funding tied into studying climate change, which may be genuine in motive but has a way of deciding for scientists what they'll study and potentially what results they'll draw. Politics and money polluting scientific integrity is not a new concept and one we shouldn't overlook in measuring the level of concern over climate change.

@Tristan Collins 
1. Jimmy Kimmel isn't a scientist. 

2. Ice cores are only one way of assessing temperatures and atmospheric changes. There are other ways. 

And the only people disputing the accuracy of ice cores are climate change deniers. It's like saying that evolution is disputed. It's not expect by people who are scientifically ignorant.

We've been able to gauge temperatures and atmospheric changes going back a LOT longer than the 1850s.

3. Yes, there are cycles, but when you see an anomaly, as we are seeing right now, then it's a sign of a problem.

This excuse doesn't carry any water and is easily debunked by even a little research on the subject.

Please do it.

4. There are sources that show that aliens built the pyramids, but they aren't legit. 

The reason you can't find it is because it's not legitimate. 

When the scientific consensus says one thing, and one or two sources say something else, the one or two sources are most likely wrong. And if they're not, they need to show pretty conclusive evidence they aren't. And those sources have not.

5. Lots and lots of third party, unbiased sources have researched it and nearly all of them have reached the exact same conclusion. 

This denial that climate change is real is akin to denying evolution. It's made by ignorant people who let their own beliefs get in the way of what is true.

To your first comment, that was in reference to Jimmy's comment on the 15 year warm spell. To your second comment, we've been keeping records for a very short amount of time, about the 1850s, as compared to the time line of natural history. Yeah yeah there are ice cores, but its accuracy is disputed. To your third comment, what is over the long term? The earth has a history of hot and cold spells that slowly scale up for hundreds or thousands of years then scale back down. To the fourth comment, there were sources showing the correlation to be reversed but I cannot locate them atm, sorry. The two do inform each other. And the fifth comment, Of course! That's what happens when its not an unbiased third party doing the studies. (Id argue that govt money has a motive.) Don't get me wrong, Im not cheerleading for the oil companies. Overall, we should diversify energy options and look for renewable options- the current "green" options are not up to snuff yet.

+Tristan Collins  *_"You also cannot study climate in terms of the past decade or decades. The public conversation changes from global warming to global cooling and vice versa every 20-30 years as the climate swings."_*

No, you can't study climate change in terms of the last decade. And scientists don't do that. So I'm not sure why you're bringing it up.

*_"Climate naturally cycles through cold periods and warm periods. "_*

Yes, climate changes go through cycles, but over the longterm, the earth IS getting warmer. That is what the scientific evidence is saying.

*_"In terms of carbon dioxide, the levels scale up proportionally after temperature goes up- not before."_*

No, that's not true. That's simply a lie. 

*_"There is a lot of funding tied into studying climate change, which may be genuine in motive but has a way of deciding for scientists what "_*

And you're trying to suggest there isn't MORE money available to those who deny climate change? Are you even aware of the fact that the vast majority of papers published AGAINST global warming are paid for by the oil industry? And the oil industry was actually aware of global warming well before the scientific community was, but hid that fact.

So you're wrong on every single count.

Why is there no doubt that we can survive any breaking point?

@Daniel Donoghue
 That question is exactly why global warming seems an alarmist concept.  It will never be a sudden global famine.  There may be a gradual decline in crop yield, and we have yet to see that.  Theory can't predict what will happen.  Crop failures in some parts of the world may be compensated by harvests elsewhere.  Climate change is so gradual that we have the luxury of time to wait and see.  In fact, we won't decide how much global warming is tolerable until we reach a breaking point, and there is no doubt we can survive every breaking point.  By the way, in the 1970s, there was a fear of an ice age.
So people don't trust the science. If famine occurs who will people/governments turn to for a solution? and why?

@Daniel Donoghue
 It's not that the public and politicians don't understand the science; they don't trust it any more than a weather forecast one month in advance.  (Similarly, they may understand the science behind a weather forecast, but they may not trust its accuracy.)  There is no doubt that societies around the world are waiting for irrefutable evidence in the form of breaking points; the question is how many breaking points we are willing to confirm before doing anything.  If it takes a famine, so be it.  No industrialized country on Earth has ever considered reducing, let alone stopping, the use of hydrocarbons to avert a climate catastrophe.

So because politicians and the general public don't understand science we just don't do anything? Rather than listen to scientists who do understand the evidence? Also, hypothetically lets that say crops fail, lets pick wheat and rice, mass famine across the globe, what then? who do you think is going to find a solution?

@Daniel Donoghue
 Scientific measurements and predictions mean nothing to non-scientists, and even less to politicians.  It takes nothing less than a breaking point, however bad, to impact people's lives and verify global warming is real.  There are many ways to have a breaking point.  If science predicts climate disasters, but they don't happen, science is wrong.  We need to reach a breaking point before doing something is easier than doing nothing.

Well a breaking point is not very specific, I would argue that we are already seeing this breaking point. The problem with using that as a measure is that you can keep moving the goal post. 

Also, waiting for a breaking point is really not a good idea. Should we wait for food to become scarce? For species to become extinct? for sea levels to rise and cover cities? 

It also doesn't work to just go "food is scarce so climate change is real", that is not independent verification of anything, climate change is complex. We know CO2 levels are rising, we know the ocean is becoming more acidic, we know temperatures are rising. So we can do experiments and observations based on recorded trends of these factors and predict outcomes (i..e. additional CO2 does X to X plant)

@Daniel Donoghue
 If global warming affects our food, then the evidence has to come in the form of a *breaking point*, such as a new scarcity of some types of food due solely to climate change.  That would be independent verification of global warming.  But until that happens, global warming is only theory and fear mongering.  Unless a breaking point has confirmed global warming (i.e. has affected my life), world leaders have been doing exactly the right thing -- listening to the scientific community, but doing nothing.

Many scientists admit a minor increase in temperatures over the past century, the legitimate debate between scientists is whether or not is worth of concern. The problem is when politicians (both left and right), businesses, media, and interest groups dramatize and over-publicize the issue to their own benefit. 

Note that a minority of scientists, even those who do believe climate change will eventually be an issue, actually think buying all of the anti-doomsday products are going to save the world. The greenhouse effect is real and the majority of that effect is caused by water vapor. Out of all of the C0^2, which generates a small minority of the greenhouse effect, all of human society produces a minority. The real debate among scientists is between those who say "That minority is causing an issue, and one day this could be bad" and those who say "That minority is not necessarily the primary cause, and it is not very serious." Real scientists (e.g. those who are not paid to be extroverts) are not screaming doomsday, regardless of what those on the left or those on the right think. There is a legitimate discussion, but that real discussion is ignored in favor of the flamboyant doomsday prophets on the left and conspiracy theorists on the right.

While I can't tell you what it will take to get through to a climate denier, science does give us an idea of where the minimum bar to convince them is set. 

The biggest indicator of warming is Ocean Heat Content, (search NOAA OHC 0-2000m). In the last 40 years or so the top 2000m of ocean have stored an extra 2.5x10^23 joules of energy. 

This energy is the equivalent of half the impact of the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs. That energy was delivered at a rate equal to about 200+ A bombs per minute every minute for the last 40 years to the oceans. None of this convinced a denier. 

So by equivalence, it would take more than 200 A bombs a minute or half a dinosaur killer to convince a climate change denier.

Hi. Who wants to talk facts? Source: NASA

NASA's Armstrong Flight Research Center is engaged in a 40 year study of Antarctica. It's currently performing airborne polar ice thickness reconnaissance in a DC8 planes, topographically mapping the thickness of the continental ice shelves in Antarctica. The radar equipped plane can actually see under the ice, allowing accurate tracking of any change in the ice mass of the polar shelf, it's the most sophisticated radar system, world-wide. The plane flies at 1500 feet with equipment that detect any change in the polar ice up to 5 cm in size. It is currently changing up to 7 meters per year and they have been flying these reconnaissance ice mapping missions since 1992 and with that data sample size, you can witness the change in the ice over the decades.

Antarctica holds 90 percent of the world's ice and 70% of the world's fresh water. @fenrisvargen Climate sensitivity to carbon dioxide can be measured empirically by comparing past temperature changes to natural forcings occurring at that time. At present, the evidence indicates that a doubling of atmospheric CO2 over pre-industrial levels will produce a direct warming result of 1.5 to 4.5 degrees C _(Lourius 1990, Hoffert 1992, Hansen 1993, Gregory 2002, Chylek 2007, Tung 2007, Shwartz 2007 & 2008, Bender 2010)_.

Climate sensitivity cannot be pinpointed to exact figures owing to the enormous complexity of the systems involved. However, multiple vectors of empirical research have narrowed the figures to within a high-confidence range of 1.5-4.5 degrees C.

During the Pliocene, three million years ago, temperatures were 3 degrees higher than today's pre-industrial levels. The northern hemisphere was free of glaciers and ice sheets, beech trees grew in the Transantarctic mountains, sea levels were 25 metres higher, and atmospheric carbon dioxide levels were 360-400 ppm. _[Climate Dynamics 26, 249-365, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 103, 39, 14288-93]_.

@MrDunedon _"Givoe me a summary of the methodology used to arrive at that figure. In words, no links."_

A group of 4000 volunteers was assigned the task of evaluating the abstracts of 12,000 peer-reviewed scientific papers about climate change. Papers which expressed a position on anthropogenic climate change were categorized as endorsing the phenomenon, not endorsing the phenomenon, or taking no position. Each paper was evaluated twice. The identities of co-evaluators were not known to each other. In cases of disagreement, papers were evaluated by a third volunteer. The volunteers were an internationally diverse group from Australia, USA, Canada, UK, New Zealand, Germany, Finland, and Italy. The received zero funding and operated on a purely volunteer basis.

To correlate their findings, 8,500 authors of the evaluated papers were contacted to articulate whether their publication endorsed, did not endorse, or took no position on anthropogenic climate change. 1,200 authors responded, confirming the position taken by 2,400 papers.

Of the 12,000 papers evaluated, 4,000 took an explicit position on anthropogenic climate change, and 97.1% of these endorsed the phenomenon. Of the 2,400 papers authored by scientists responding to the study, 1,400 took an explicit position on anthropogenic climate change, and 97.2% of these endorsed the phenomenon. These findings were consistent with the _Doran, Zimmerman (2009)_ study which found a 97.4% consensus, and the _Anderegg et al. (2010)_ study which found a 97.0% consensus.

@fenrisvargen You are moving the goalposts. The original post asked why people don't accept the reality of climate change. Individuals who accept the reality of climate change but are skeptical about its ramifications do not belong under this heading, and are thereby not the people I described.

Regardless, the climactic ramifications of doubling atmospheric carbon dioxide are as clear and unmistakable as the health ramifications of running a car in a closed garage.

Climate sensitivity to carbon dioxide can be measured empirically by comparing past temperature changes to natural forcings occurring at that time. At present, the evidence indicates that a doubling of atmospheric CO2 over pre-industrial levels will produce a direct warming result of 1.5 to 4.5 degrees C _(Lourius 1990, Hoffert 1992, Hansen 1993, Gregory 2002, Chylek 2007, Tung 2007, Shwartz 2007 & 2008, Bender 2010)_. This direct warming excludes feedback mechanisms which amplify the planet's heat retentive capacity. During the last ice age, average surface temperatures were 3-4 degrees C cooler than they are today.

We know the sensitivity of the planet's climate systems is within the 1.5-4.5 degrees C range, and we know that doubling atmospheric CO2 will cause a 1.5-4.5 degree increase in average surface temperature. Because we know these things, we know that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are dangerous to the stability of climate systems. If you disagree with this, it means you disagree with the evidence, i.e., what is known. If you disagree with what is known, it means you are plainly incorrect.

+Andreas Ryge There are about 96 million head of cattle in the US alone. That is more than three times as much livestock as there were bison at the height of their population and with that comes about three times as much greenhouse gas emissions. Farming is an industry just like any other, the fact that it's product is alive does not change the fact that it is a huge contributor to climate change. That being said, livestock contributes about 13-18% of greenhouse gas emissions, not most. 

But here is where it gets interesting. Methane (the greenhouse gas that livestock produces) is about 100x more effective at trapping heat from the sun as CO2. So, 13-18% of the gas would cause much more than 50% of the greenhouse effect. On the other hand methane stays in the atmosphere for about 10 years, while CO2 can take decades or even centuries to leave. So, for short-term effects +Gavin Caesar is right, while for the long-term, you could argue no.

the empirical evidence for the attribution of rising atmospheric CO2 since the Industrial Revolution to fossil fuel emissions is a correlation between cumulative emissions and cumulative changes in atmospheric CO2; and the empirical evidence for the attribution of warming to fossil fuel emissions is a correlation between cumulative emissions and cumulative warming. thus, empirical evidence of AGW rests entirely on correlations between cumulative values. the  problem is that correlations between cumulative values are spurious. please see

Oh nice, I also took a course on global warming in the spring of my senior year at UW 2 years ago. I can honestly say I didn't really buy it before that class. That class provided evidence that was compelling enough for me to change my view. Should compelling evidence against global warming emerge, I'll be the first to admit I was wrong. Like I said, all I care about is demonstrable truth.

"If a person has difficulty accepting new views even after having been presented with irrefutable facts that overwhelmingly support those new views, that person is the one failing to align with reality."

Well arguably both of you are failing to align with reality. There are simply people who are swayed more by their feelings than logic.

But I have taken a college level course about global warming and an introductory college geology course preceding that. They present plausible relationships between variables, but they're not always conclusive, and sometimes can be explained with alternative theories.

I'll just say that in practice science is _way_ fuzzier than what we expect of it in theory. It's because we think that as long as we have the data, we'll just use logic to make the right conclusion. But there is so much data out there that just "applying logic" really isn't that easy. In any statistical analysis, there are tons of factors regarding what sample you pick, how much testing you do, what variables to include and which ones not to, and you can have lots of disagreement on what method is actually a fair representation of the data.

I have taken some classes on income taxes so I could use that as another example. Theoretically, the government has all the laws laid out for us, and we just have to apply the rules to fill out the tax form correctly. Yet every tax expert will come up with a different number from the last. There are so many tax laws that it's literally impossible to remember all of them and their nuances. There are going to be certain human limitations in "applying the logic" of the law. So yeah, tax experts actually will develop some _subjective_ feelings from a presumably _objective_ set of rules because of the practical trouble in applying so many rules precisely.

The point is that the real world has too many variables to represent it all in precise, objective terms. We try to, by making guidelines, and putting things into simplified graphs and charts. I'm not saying that isn't highly useful, but there are always going to be inherent limitations to that and we need the humility to at least admit that.

If a person has difficulty accepting new views even after having been presented with irrefutable facts that overwhelmingly support those new views, that person is the one failing to align with reality. Demonstrable truth is ALL I care about. I have no political stake in this issue and would agree some have used it for political advantage. I dont find them any less deplorable. I maintain that if Americans had a working, active knowledge of basic biology, chemistry and physics you would have way fewer climate change deniers.

@Michael Hemming
Well, it's pretty hard to change a person's views, depending on the person. So there definitely is a decent amount of idealism in what you're saying. I'm not saying just rule it out, but you have to question how much your ideals align with reality, if they do at all.

@KodachiC
You can be an atheist and still find some other reason to deny climate change. I'm just saying you shouldn't take the typical line of reasoning used for certain views as the defining ones. In fact atypical lines of reasoning are often more promising if you think about it -- if fewer people thought of a certain line of reasoning, it might be because it's too complicated/sophisticated for the public to find it attractive or understandable -- but it might be a stronger argument nonetheless. So you still want to have a response for atypical arguments for/against climate change, not just the ones you're most used to.

It's still possible to think that the other side just has a brain error because they don't hold your view, while still being wrong. The trouble is that the other side of a debate will probably look dumb to you if you don't agree with it. If it made sense to you, why would you agree with it? But the problem is that when a disagreement arises, you don't know how much of that is your fault, and how much is theirs. Of course you'd like to say that it's theirs every single time, that it's always _them_ that is committing the intellectual mistake and not you, but then that can lead to bias.

THE EMBARRASSING BOMB-TEST-CURVE
"Why all the fuss about carbon? It only stays in the atmosphere for 10 years.

During the 1950s and 1960s, several nations performed atmospheric tests of nuclear weapons. The radiation effects of these tests produced large amounts of C14-carbon dioxide (14CO2) in the air. 14C is an isotope of carbon, the common isotope being 12C. When the bomb tests ceased in 1963, the atmospheric level of 14CO2 had been raised to about twice its previous natural value. This extra 14CO2 can be used as a tracer for tracking the movement of carbon through the natural world – the Carbon Cycle. This wonderfully serendipitous experiment would be hard to beat even if someone designed it.

Over the following half-century the amount of 14CO2 measured in the global atmosphere diminished in a text-book exponential manner as shown in the diagrams above.

14C is radioactive but this curve is not the radioactive decay curve. The half-life of radioactive 14C is 5,730 years , whereas the half-time of the bomb-test curve is only 10 years, i.e. after 10 years only half was left, after 20 years, one quarter was left, after 30 years, only one eighth and so on.

The half-time of CO2 in the atmosphere is of great interest to climate modellers. They assume that CO2 is removed from the atmosphere according to a theoretical curve called the “Bern Model” or a similar curve called the ISAM model. The blue line in the lower panel shows predicted atmospheric decay curve of 14CO2 according to the Bern Model. It is quite different to the observed curve.

The Bern Model utilises four different half-times and does not return to nearly zero after 60 years as does the bomb-test curve. According to the Bern Model it will take centuries for 14CO2 (and anthropogenic CO2) to be ultimately removed from the atmosphere. The modellers chose to adopt the more alarmist scenario despite the fact that it is “non-physical” (i.e. obviously wrong).

Admittedly it is complicated: CO2 reacts with water chemically and this slows down the rate at which it dissolves. Furthermore, while there is a fast interchange of gases between the atmosphere and the top 100 metres or so of the ocean called the “mixed layer” (~70 Gt per year), it is widely assumed that there is much less transport through the bottom of the mixed layer (~2 Gt per year, IPCC figures). The latter is the reason for the flattening out of the Bern Model curve at times longer than 60 years.

But despite these quibbles about the half-time and the shape of the curve, one incontrovertible fact remains:

In 50 years nearly all the bomb-test 14CO2 has disappeared!

Since the 14CO2 reaction rates, solubilities and diffusion times are very similar to those 12CO2, this implies that all the ordinary atmospheric CO2 in the atmosphere at the time of the bomb test has completely changed over.

Where has all the 14CO2 gone?

There are various possible CO2 reservoirs, e.g. the biosphere and the mixed layer, but the problem is that these are roughly same size as the atmosphere. A new equilibrium would be soon be reached wherein the bomb 14CO2 would be partitioned between the reservoirs in proportion to their capacity, so causing the bomb 14CO2 in the atmosphere to level off in a similar way to the Bern model curve.

Instead it tends to zero. That this happens implies that the bomb 14CO2 has either been transported to a reservoir that is much, much larger than the atmosphere or it has left the ocean-atmosphere system.

It is commonly accepted that approximately 38,000 Gt of CO2 are dissolved in the deep ocean, more than 100 times the amount generated by humans since the start of the industrial revolution. The deep ocean is larger than any other conceivable reservoir. Either the missing 14C is sequestered in the deep ocean or it has been removed altogether, perhaps as carbonate in the skeletal material of sea creatures.

WOCE – the World Ocean Circulation Experiment produced detailed maps of the major constituents of the oceans in the mid-1990s. The WOCE Atlas is on-line and it is certainly worth a look; oceanography at its very best. The Pacific Ocean maps and sections are the most detailed and complete.

One of the chemical signatures mapped by WOCE is delta 14C, the proportion of 14C above the background level. Here is a map of delta 14C in the Pacific Ocean at a depth of 200 metres: .."

I'm not saying I don't buy it. It's just that I'm not going to base my thoughts purely on a "100% real science" label. (parodying a "made with real cheese" label on a food product :) ) I'm going to think a bit, well, what does that really mean. I might still conclude that I believe it, just not in a zombie-like manner.

But yeah, I think it can depend on the type of issue. The more indirect your evidence, the more speculation there can be. In a high school experiment it's simple. To the point where, everyone should agree on the results. When you're dealing with climate, that involves zillions of concurrent processes on Earth, it's way harder to organize the variables, and it does make room for bias, absolutely, because you start to have to rely on judgment. You have to pick what to examine, because you don't have time to pick everything. That does pave the way for educated, but judgment related guesses.

Stats for example can be presented in tons of different ways. So, yes, a person's associations might lead them to look at them in one way first, or weight it more heavily, etc. To what extent do I know that would happen? Not much, but again, that's because I'm not involved in peer review. And you're not in a higher place of knowledge regarding that, because you aren't either. Unless you're a scientist, in which case, well, then we can talk a bit haha.

Think about it. If you wanted to show the connection between two things, you have an infinite amount of variables to pick from. So how do you decide on your hypothesis? It's going to be a judgment call. But the hypotheses you start with will affect your path to the conclusion. The trouble is when there are many other hypotheses that are consistent with certain data.

Well yeah, I'm not involved in peer review, so how would I know? :) You're in the same boat. You're not involved with peer review. It's just that I'm honest about it. I say that peer review might be carried out in x way, or y way, etc., but I don't commit myself because I'm aware that there is only so much I can know about a process I don't observe.

Addicts are treated like criminals, their lives are likewise destroyed by the stigma of using, and then they have nothing left but the drugs, in a cruel twist of fate.

And, since the sentencing for drugs is so terrible, it's high risk, so you literally get a bunch of psychopaths running the drug scene, building gangs, etc.

Psychopaths feel little to no remorse, and they are very likely to take risks and not think about the consequences. That's just their neural wiring. It's a lot different from yours or mine. They end up being socially engaging and manipulative as well, so they end up being the ones actually producing and operating these gangs.

These people will always exist - their social fearlessness also makes their reproductive success high.

So, that's the system that you face. You can respond angrily - or you can do what works and systematically decriminalize drugs so that the economics of actually dealing doesn't actually make the drugs expensive.

They should still be illegal, but the "penalty" should be rehab.

It's tough to think this way - I know the urge for justice and revenge is a strong one.

@pplr1 It does not matter if Washington Post actually talked to scientists because it is a media source.  They can post whatever they want, in whatever context they want, and omit anything they want, including scientists who believe satellites are more accurate.  

This is the importance of peer review, is that peer review has strong filters for nonsense.  This is why we use peer review over media sources, because it produces more reliable results.

I have confirmed nothing.  For the  past 20-26 years, there has been no global warming.  This is a fact according to two measurements of the lower troposphere (UAH & RSS), which both agree remarkably well.  This is established in the peer review as well (will link to paper if interested).

+Global Warming Skeptic 


1.  If you read the Washington Post article they interviewed actual scientists who I strongly suspect do publish in peer reviewed journals.

Plus, last I heard neither Ted Cruz nor the rightwing propagandist that runs climatedepot are scientists nor are their publications per reviewed.

Your comment tells me you said I didn't provide evidence without even bothering to read the article I pointed to.

And in my earlier comment I very much did point out that the article interviewed actual scientists (who have looked into the topic you brought up).

3.  No.  Simply no. There are years in the 1990s with no El Ninos, and they are generally warmer than years with no El Ninos in the 1980s.

On top of that, even without being a climate scientist I'm pretty sure the general understanding of an El Nino is that one occurs for a couple years and spiking the temp for those years rather than a decade so it is not "thought to have been responsible for the accelerated warming of the late 80s through 1998".

And even if I were to take your notion that El Ninos warm a whole decade rather than a couple of years that doesn't contradict either the point global warming is occurring (which some have claimed even if you aren't right now) or that it is man made.  At best it simply says global warming is happening but at a slower rate.  So I guess thanks for confirming Global Warming is real (and thus a problem).

@pplr1 #1 -- You used Washington Post as a source.  Washington Post is not a peer reviewed scientific journal, nor are they scientists.

#2 -- You state that surface temperatures are more accurate, but you give not a shred of data.  Satellites measure the lower troposphere temperature (first 10 miles).  This is where the Greenhouse Effect has its strongest impact, as GH gases settle down to lower levels of the atmosphere since CO2 and  H2O (water vapor) are heavier than air.  This is why the lower troposphere as a whole is more important.  

The temperature at the first few meters of the atmosphere isn't neraly as meaningful as longwave radiation from the lower troposphere as a whole.

#3 -- The claim is that there has been no global warming for 20-26 or more years.  This is of statistical significance because, at minimum, even if you were to take it back more than 20 years, there has been a deceleration in the amount of warming despite a rapid acceleration in human greenhouse emissions.

That's not even removing the El Nino signal, which is now thought to have been responsible for the accelerated warming of the late 80s through 1998.

Also, pointing to a single month and saying "warmest on record" is a meaningless statement.

@Danny Puran
 Don't use stats from countries you don't understand (and don't understand how their stats are generated):

Statistical factors:
Unlike the majority of countries in Europe, crime data in Sweden are collected when the offence in question is first reported, at which point the classification may be unclear.


In Sweden, once an act has been registered as rape, it retains this classification in the published crime statistics, even if later investigations indicate that no crime can be proven or if the offence must be given an alternative judicial classification.


Sweden also applies a system of expansive offence counts. Other countries may employ more restrictive methods of counting. The Swedish police registers one offence for each person raped, and if one and the same person has been raped on a number of occasions, one offence is counted for each occasion that can be specified. For example, if a woman says she has been raped by her husband every day during a year, the Swedish police may record more than 300 cases of rape. In many other countries only a single offence would be counted in such a situation

@Clint Rhea A distorted consensus that is being deliberately distorted by many people for their own political and financial gain. Did you even read any of what I wrote about how Cook et al's 97% is a total misrepresentation?

@Eric Duprey, this isn't simply a "majority rules" argument. There is an acknowledged consensus by the world's leading climate minds and organizations that humans are causing global warming. That's simply a fact.

@Clint Rhea At least one of the most common sources for the 97% claim is complete rubbish. Cook et al, 2013, found that out of all published papers in the time frame he analyzed, 97% that took a position one way or the other on warming stated that warming is occurring and human released CO2 contributes *to some degree*. 

Cook found that 1.6% of papers go further, saying both that warming is occurring and that human released CO2 is the main cause. In a later paper Bedford and Cook, 2013, he misrepresented the latter category as the former, claiming that his earlier paper showed 97% of papers claimed warming is occurring and human released CO2 was the main cause.

Treating 1.6% as 97% is misleading at best, a deliberate distortion at worst. 

Since then, more papers have tried to show through surveys that this number is a 90%+ majority, and I haven't reviewed those. To be honest, I don't really care too much about the majority view. I care about the science itself. Majorities are routinely wrong about very important things.

@Eric Duprey, they didn't have to cherry-pick for anything but humor here. As mentioned over and over in the video we're watching (with a source: NASA), 97% of all publishing climate scientists agree that humans are causing global warming. You're free to disagree, but you haven't proven your opinion is worth listening to.

I appreciate your response because you provided evidence to support your claim that "people don't care about climate change...compared to many other things...." However, the Gallup poll you cite is two years old and there has been a lot more discussion about climate change in those two years, not to mention the advent of the Paris Agreements, which was historic. But even in the poll you cite, a combined 49% of people were concerned about climate change either a fair amount or a great deal. In other words, roughly half of all people WERE concerned about climate change. That's not anywhere near your allegation or implication that "people don't care." 

A more recent Gallup poll, one from this year, shows that those who are concerned about climate change either a fair or great amount has risen by 30% (or 15 percentage points) to 64%, to nearly two out of three. More and more people are seeing the results and effects of climate change and the deniers are in decline.

http://www.gallup.com/poll/190010/concern-global-warming-eight-year-high.aspx

A larger poll done by the Pew Research Center shows there is a more concern about climate change in other parts of the world. This poll is from April of this year (the Gallup Poll I cited was done a month earlier.)

In the U.S. alone, animals raised for food produce 130 times more excrement than the entire human population—86,000 pounds per second. A typical pig factory farm generates as much raw waste as a city of 50,000 people. Chicken, pig, and cow excrement have polluted over 35,000 miles of rivers in at least 22 states and contaminated groundwater in at least 17 states.

+Susan Callery Of all agricultural land in the U.S., nearly 80 percent is used to raise animals for food. More than 260 million acres of U.S. forest have been cleared to create cropland to grow grain for animal feed, and about 85 percent of the seven billion tons of topsoil lost in the U.S. each year has been directly attributed to the enslavement of cows. +Android Miller Could I try to explain the phenomenon of increased ice at the poles in regards to the topic, as it is actually proof of global climate change. The temperature that ice freezes at is affected by the salt content of the water; the higher the concentration of salt, the lower the temperature the water must be for it to freeze. Because of higher temperatures, the freshwater glaciers melted and lowered the concentration of salt at the poles. As a result the water around the poles freeze at a higher temperature, which accounts for the greater amount of ice. We can tell because ice saples from the newly frozen ice, which by the way melts and refreezes every year, shows that the ice is now frozen saltwater not freshwater as it was before. It is this low salt concentration salt water caused by the melting of freshwater glaciers that is causing the ice refreezong at the poles to increase.

Thumbs down in less than 10 seconds. The graph in the beginning is completely false, they removed the medieval warm period, the roman warm period and the little ice age. This historically proven and whoever came up with that graph is a liar.

The Medieval and Roman warm periods were neither global, globally synchronous nor multidecadal. Today's warming is all three. Nobody removed the Little Ice Age. It's right there in the graph.

You're apparently thinking of the famous Medieval Warm period schematic (created by Hubert Lamb)
that clearly shows a big bump of warming, higher than today's warming. The schematic has been reprinted hundreds of times throughout the denier blogosphere. But what they don't tell you is that the graph only represented the climate of central England and western Europe, not the entire world. Even more striking, they neglect to share that the schematic ends in 1950, leaving out our very warmest decades.

That's why the Medieval Warm Period looks so trivial in this graph by comparison. This is WORLD climate, not that of Central England, and it includes our very hottest decades.

Climate change or not, investing and shifting to renewables is smart. Fossil fuels will run out, and are literally dirty. Over 8 million people die each year from fossil fuel air pollution, and millions more are harmed, making the health care costs almost incalculable. They destroy potable groundwater wells, destroy arable farmland, destroy metals in cities from acid rain and on and on and on. Considering all these factors, fossil fuels are not cheaper than most established renewables. Wind, in particular, is waaaay cheaper than all fossil fuels when all subsidies are removed from the fossil fuels and taking into account the societal costs.
Sure, the US has 1.2 million jobs in the fossil fuel industry, but how many millions of jobs are missed because they don't want to develop the renewables market? They would have the entire world as their costumers, especially Europe and parts of Asia.

An example: Denmark is the largest fossil fuel producer in the EU, but after the oil crisis in the 70's, they vowed to work towards never being reliant on other countries for such an important societal product. They developed the fossil fuel industry at home, while at the same time investing heavily in developing the technologies for wind power and other renewables, by using the money gained from the fossil fuels, because they knew the fossil fuels wouldn't last forever.
On the other hand, the UK had the same opportunity, but politically said wind was a waste of money, and didn't invest in it. The result? Denmark became the largest producer of wind turbines, making it the largest industry in the country and had at one point employed more people than any one industry in the country - almost 50,000 people at one point. This considering that there were only slightly over 5 million people in the entire country back then.
Over time, oil and gas revenues fell but renewables became bigger and bigger. It's still one of the largest industries in the country. Now Denmark has seen another opportunity to sell renewables to the rest of the EU, and at the same time helping other countries reach their CO2 reduction goals, by building a $34 billion artifical energy island, that will at full development power over 6 million homes - more than the entire population in Denmark. This same island will use excess wind power to power the largest hydrogen plant in the world; hydrogen that can be sold to other countries as a storage medium when wind and sun are insufficient, as well as creating artificial CO2 neutral carbon based fuels to power vehicles, planes and traditional powerplants.
How is this island funded, you may ask? 51% will be owned by the government and the 49% being owned by private enterprices, including the largest energy companies in the country (including current fossil fuel producers).

Many climate change deniers say "but renewables are unreliable". That's very true, but the country that can solve that very problem efficiently will become the undisputed leader and earner of an entire energy sector, just like large fossil fuel producing countries in the world are now, and just like Denmark became when they basically invented the commercial scale wind turbines.

@Steve Richfield  There is no way to stop sea level rise anytime soon. Correct. We already have a damaging amount of sea level rise baked into the system from our warming. But that doesn't mean we ignore future flooding 50,100 or 150 years from now by failing to act now. If greenhouse gas emissions continue unabated,  we could see a one meter sea level rise by 2100. With steep reductions in fossil fuel burning, we could slash that in half, according to the IPCC. 

Each year of sea level rise gives storm surges and king tides higher platforms to launch from. A large storm surge can already flood miles inland. Shoreline cities and towns won't have to wait until complete inundation. According to FEMA, it takes only an inch of flooding in the average home to cause $25000 in damage. It's why Miami Beach has already spent a half a billion dollars elevating seawalls, moving buildings and raising 105 miles of roads and why New York has a new $10 billion-dollar flood mitigation project in the works. 

Half of our C02 emissions are NOT absorbed by plants or any other natural sinks. Plants are already absorbing all they can.  https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/earth-stopped-getting-greener-20-years-ago/

In addition, the C02 benefit isn't quite what scentists originally thought it was after measuring NASA's satellite data a few years back. A new assessment has been made since, and it turns out that a large portion of the "greening" the satellites saw was from the planting of billions of trees by Chna, India and Europe, and not so much from natural C02-induced growth. 

Scientists have weighed both sides of this debate and have determined that the damage will be far greater than the benefits. There is no shortage of data showing that.

If you look at a map of the world, there is little arable farmland near the equator. Most of it is Sahara desert and a narrow neck of mountainous land in Central America. We arguably should be opting to maximize total farm production, which will come with more farmland growing higher yields due to the increase in CO2.

Here where I live near Seattle, the weeds are growing wildly. I must now regularly hack back overgrowing blackberry bushes due to the increased CO2. While this is an inconvenience, I see that this is really a good thing, as it is a part of increasing farm yields worldwide.

Hence, though I acknowledge the arguments of the Climate Change people, I also recognize the arguments of the so-called Deniers. @Steve Richfield I agree that warming is not ALL bad. The big winners will indeed be countries in northern and far northern latitudes. Russia is delighted with what's happening. Not only do they end up with more farmland as the permafrost melts, the melting Arctic opens up new shipping lanes for them. 

I happen to live in an area that already has a mix of benefits and damage. Our shrimp fishery completely collapsed because of the warming waters but on the other hand winters have historically been brutal here and none of us is complaining about the milder temperatures and earlier springs now. Growng season has expanded by a full week, which is great news for farmers and gardeners. But on the other hand, ticks are now surviving the milder winters when they tended to die out before, so we now have the highest rates of Lyme Disease in the world. 
The disease is rampant here and because of its severity, it has stopped many of us from roaming the woods and fields as we used to. 

At the end of the day, the worldwide calculations of damage to benefits ratio is that there will be more damage than benefit, especially among the hundreds of millions of us who live along shorelines vulnerable to sea level rise. Throughout most of the 20th century, sea level rise averaged 1.5mm per year. Today it's 5mm per year and accelerating, according to the World Meteorological Organization. According to NOAA, high tide flooding along the American northeast has jumped 140% in just 20 years. It's up an astonishing 190% along the southeast. Where will it be 50 years from now?

Increasing heat in equatorial regions will also make growing crops there impossible. Many crops and plants have a heat limit, when photosynthesis, growth, and even germination of seeds stop. There is a temperature limit of what humans and animals will endure as well. 250 million years ago, high C02 drove temperatures to 140 degrees in equatorial regions and caused a mass extinction event. That would be our worst case scenario, obviously.

My take on this matter is as follows. All life on earth is carbon based. Before life, in the pre-cambrian, carbon in the air was about 5000 ppm. Tree life on land locked its carbon up in coal. Michael Crichton, one of my all-time favorite authors, was not a climate scientist and it showed. He wrote a novel, not a scientific paper, and he took liberties to misrepresent the data. The scientists whose work he referenced cried foul very loudly after his book was published. 

The term "global warming" was not changed to "climate change." Climate change has been used in scientific journals since the 1950s. They are two entirely different terms. Global warming denotes warming, obviously, but "climate change" is used to encompass warming and all of its effects: changes in air and ocean currents, disturbances of the jet stream, migration of the snow/rain line, increases in extreme precipitation events, droughts and wildfires, intensification of hurricanes and more.

It was Republican strategist Frank Luntz, ironically, who popularized the term and made it go viral after he warned Republicans to never utter the term "global warming" ever again because it sounded too scary, and he advised them to use climate change instead. Look it up.

1. The earth has not stopped warming. 19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 tied for first.
2. Nobody changed the term "global warming" to "climate change." "Climate change" has been used in scientific journals since the 1950s. They are two different things. Climate change is a more encompassing term because in addition to warming, it denotes all of the side effects that come with warming: migration of the rain/snow line, disturbance of the jet stream, changes in air and ocean currents, increases in extreme precipitation events, droughts, and wildfires, and intensification of hurricanes.
3. Wildfires have always happened.  Today they happen more often because global warming is accelerating evaporation, drying out tinder and vegetation and making it much more likely to ignite and spread. We have advanced fire-fighting equipment today and much earlier reporting when a fire breaks out; we have more access roads to reach fires, and air power to help control the flames, all things we did not have a century ago. 
4. Since 1995 there have been 18 above-normal Atlantic hurricane seasons, as measured by NOAA’s Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) Index. ACE calculates the intensity of a hurricane season by combining the number, wind speed and duration of each tropical cyclone. That’s the largest stretch of above-normal seasons on record. So while there aren’t necessarily more Atlantic hurricanes than before, those that form are getting stronger, with more Category 4 and 5 events. 

Fewer people die from hurricanes today because of our advanced warning systems, mandatory evacuations and modern rescue services.

@Alterss Bot It certainly appears counterintuitive, but while water vapor can absorb more heat, C02 is more powerful because it's the glue that holds the entire greenhouse system together, and C02 provides its heat-trapping ability for CENTURIES, while water vapor, as I said, only hangs around for hours or days. 

Don't take my word for it. Here's NASA's opinion: https://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/abs/la09300d.html "Ample physical evidence shows that carbon dioxide (CO2) is the single most important climate-relevant greenhouse gas in Earth's atmosphere. This is because CO2, like ozone, N2O, CH4, and chlorofluorocarbons, does not condense and precipitate from the atmosphere at current climate temperatures, whereas water vapor can, and does. Non-condensing greenhouse gases, which account for 25% of the total terrestrial greenhouse effect, thus serve to provide the stable temperature structure that sustains the current levels of atmospheric water vapor and clouds via feedback processes that account for the remaining 75% of the greenhouse effect. Without the radiative forcing supplied by CO2 and the other non-condensing greenhouse gases, the terrestrial greenhouse would collapse, plunging the global climate into an icebound Earth state."

Temperature is not driving C02 today. That's the fossil fuel industry's favorite meme, and it's unsupported by the scientific literature. C02 is driving temperature. 

As for acid rain, C02 is acidifying the oceans while at the same time continuing to accumulate in the atmosphere. Both things are happening at once.  So I'm not sure what the point of your question is.

@SwiftlyTiltingPlanet only 0.4% how does that make it the more powerful gree house gas. Lol. Rise in CO2 is the symptom of a warming planet...not the cause.  If CO2 remains up in the atmosphere fo centuries....then no worries fr acid rain then? Review your carbon cycle.

CO2 makes up only about 0.04% of the atmosphere, and water vapor can vary from 0 to 4%. But while water vapor is important, C02 is the more powerful greenhouse gas. Water vapor is temporary; it precipitates out. C02 does not. In fact, C02 can and does remain aloft for centuries.

Water vapor also has “windows” that allow some of our infrared energy to escape without being absorbed. In addition, water vapor is concentrated lower in the atmosphere, whereas CO2 mixes well all the way to about 50 kilometers up. The higher the greenhouse gas, the more effective it is at trapping heat from the Earth’s surface.

C02-driven warming also accelerates evaporation, which fills the atmosphere with additional moisture which then acts synergistically with C02 to magnify warming further.

For all these reasons, water vapor is considered a feedback mechanism, and not a climate forcing agent, as C02 clearly is.

@Not You Overall snow extent, according to the World Meteorologcal Organization, has actually decreased worldwide. Their data shows that it is snowing less in more and more regions while it is snowing with greater accumulations in historically cold areas, far from any snow-rain line transition zone. Snowfall and snowpack have been falling for years in Europe, China,  the western U.S. and other regions. Europe has lost 12% per decade since the 1950s. I'll link you to the data below.

 Explanation: Warming accelerates evaporation, which fills the air with additional water vapor. For every one degree C rise in temperature, the air is able to hold 7% more moisture. This results in GREATER SNOW FALL in cold, northern areas but less in the shoulder seasons and southern areas, where the snow-rain transition line is migrating to the north. That means Canada will likely see MORE snow, not less. 

It's always easy to find places that experience record cold or record snow, but we don't measure global climate change by region or by short timelines. @Not You There actually is proof that human activity is causing it. We've known for over a century that C02 traps heat and radiates it back to earth.  We also know that as C02 rises, heat rises with it.  This pairing of C02 and heat has been seen throughout millions of years of history. It's nothing new.

However, what is new is that a large portion of this C02 is coming from the burning of fossil fuels, and we know that definitively from isotopic analysis of the C02 molecules themselves. 
(They have a unique signature that differentiates them from natural C02 molecules.) 

As we've added to the total C02 in the atmosphere, spectroscopic analysis reveals more and more longwave radiation or heat bouncing back to earth. From satellite measurements, we also see the atmospheric layer above ours COOLING. That's evidence of heat being trapped below and prevented from venting back into space. 

Neither the sun nor any heat source on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the layer above it. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. And human activity is literally thickening that greenhouse. 40% of our emissions, in fact, are NOT absorbed by plants or other natural sinks. They are simply left to accumulate. For decades. For centuries.

@Dante Sunderland Actually they can and do prove that warming is anthropogenic. 
1. Spectroscopic analysis clearly shows heat passing through C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth, so we know a greenhouse effect exists. 
2. As our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it has cooled, according to NASA monitoring since 1978. That means less heat is escaping from below, further evidence of that greenhouse effect. And natural cycles can't explain why satellites measure less heat escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which CO2 absorbs (Philipona 2004, Wang 2009).
3. Isotopic analysis of our atmospheric C02 further shows that a large and growing portion of it originated specifically from the burning of fossil fuels. 40% of our emissions, in fact are not absorbed by plants or other natural sinks each year but are simply left to accumulate in the atmosphere. C02 molecules can not only accumulate and remain up there for decades, but for centuries at a time, and that's the crux of our problem. 
4. Our C02 emissions have increased since the start of the Industrial Revolution. As C02 increased, so did warming. C02 tracks with warming throughout history, dating back millions of years.
5. Major warmings of the past were always caused by one of two things: gradual changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession (Milankovitch Cycles) or massive tectonic upheaval from the break-up of continents. Neither of these factors is in play today and in fact all three Milankovitch Cycles are in cooling phases, not warming ones. 
6. The sun's last three cycles progressively weakened, reducing its heat output slightly, yet we continued to warm anyway.

High C02 in the past was caused by one of two things: (1) massive tectonic upheaval, from the break-up of continents, a process that can spew trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere over thousands of years (Google "Siberian Traps" for an astonishing example) and/or (2) Milankovitch Cycles, changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession that over thousands of years expose the northern hemisphere to increased or decreased sunlight and initiate both warm periods and major glaciations.

The sun's last three cycles progressively weakened, yet we continued to warm. Beware of Willie Soon's "It's-the-sun's-fault" mantra, which he peddles everywhere because the fossil fuel industry paid him $1.2 million to do so. His work is not supported in the scientific literature.

C02 is the most important greenhouse gas in the atmosphere because, unlike water vapor, it doesn't precipitate out. C02 molecules, by contrast, stay up there for centuries and accumulate. Methane is also fleeting because it combines with oxygen and processes into C02 after about 8 years. 

CO2 makes up only about 0.04% of the atmosphere, and water vapor can vary from 0 to 4%. But while water vapor is the dominant greenhouse gas in our atmosphere, it has “windows” that allow some of the infrared energy to escape without being absorbed. In addition, water vapor is concentrated lower in the atmosphere, whereas CO2 mixes well all the way to about 50 kilometers up. The higher the greenhouse gas, the more effective it is at trapping heat from the Earth’s surface.

Yes, C02 takes up a small amount of atmospheric space. The blanket on your bed also takes up a small amount of space in your bedroom but does a great job of keeping you warm.

Past warmings were always caused by one of two things: (1) massive tectonic upheaval, which spewed trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere and/or (2) Milankovitch Cycles, changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession. No climate scientists anywhere on this planet said countries would be submerged by the year 2000. Not even when they were drunk or high on crack. You're scoffing at your own manufactured misinformation. Here are the predictions from 40 years ago that the scientists got right:
WE WILL CONTINUE TO WARM
19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 tied for first.
THE ICE SHEETS WILL MELT
All of the world's ice sheets and 90% of its glaciers are melting at rates unprecedented in recorded history.
SEA LEVEL WILL RISE
Average sea level rise throughout most of the 20th century hovered around 1.5mm per year. In the 90s it jumped to 3mm per year. Over the past five years, according to the World Meteorological Organization, it jumped to 5mm per year.
HIGH TIDE FLOODING WILL INCREASE
According to NOAA, high tide flooding along the U.S. northeast has increased 140% in the last 20 years. It's up an astonishing 190% along the southeast.
EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS WILL INCREASE
Extreme precipitation events have not only increased worldwide, in the U.S. northeast they increased over 50% since 1960, according to the EPA. They increased 30-40% over the south, midwest and northern plains. 
HURRICANES WILL INCREASE AND INTENSIFY
Hurricanes actually haven't increased but they have intensified. Category 1 and 2 storms have decreased while category 4 and 5 storms have increased. 
GLOBAL WARMING WILL CONCENTRATE AT THE POLES
Average winter temperature in Fairbanks and Anchorage has risen 8 degrees F over the past 50 years. The extra warming at the poles is why the Arctic, Greenland and Antarctica are losing ice at a breakneck pace.

Scientists in the 70's didn't predict an ice age. Less than 10% of the papers predicted global cooling. The majority of predictions in the 70's predicted global warming. Climate models are quite accurate in predicting how the climate changes:

The sun's output never varies by more than about a half a degree up or down, even over centuries. So the sun actually has little effect in CHANGING our climate. C02, on the other hand, has a far more powerful effect in the amount of heat that escapes into space, which in turn has a dramatic effect on changing climate. It's why average winter temperature in places like Anchorage and Fairbanks has risen an astonishing 8 degrees F in just fifty years and why the icecaps are melting at rates unprecedented in recorded history. 

The earth's climate changed in the past due to Milankovitch Cycles (changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession) and/or massive tectonic upheaval that spewed trillions of tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Neither are in play today, and emissions of anthropogenic C02 are raising temperatures faster than any other time in history.

Americans per capita actually emit more C02 than China does. For a century we led the world in overall emissions, which means most of the damage in the atmosphere was done by us, not China. Almost all American adults own a car. But most Chinese adults do not. Equally important to keep in mind, China manufactures our goods for us, literally thousands of products, at low cost, which means that part of their industrial pollution is due to our own consumption. Nike and Apple, for example, make their products in China. Converse, Levis, Black and Decker, Mattel and many other American companies also have their goods made in China. Contrary to popular belief, China is actually punching above its weight class when it comes to meeting its Paris agreement goals. Alas, the U.S. walked out of its Paris agreement.

@Mountain Fisher Mars has nothing to do with earth. Its climate waxes and wanes with its orbital eccentricity (among the highest of all the planets), axial tilt,  dust storms, changes in albedo, and icecap extent. Your suggestion assumes the sun must also be warming, yet its last three cycles actually weakened. 

Spectroscopic analysis clearly identifies heat passing through C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth. Isotopic analysis clearly identifies a large portion of this C02 coming directly from the burning of fossil fuels, not nature. Further, as our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it has cooled, according to NASA satellite monitoring since 1978.  That's not the only evidence of a greenhouse effect trapping heat below, though. Satellites are measuring less heat escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which C02 absorbs. 

Neither the sun nor any warming source on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the upper one. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. 

The Medieval Warm Period was neither global, globally synchronous, nor multidecadal.Today's warming is all three. The MWP was generated by the North Atlantic Oscillation and a low period of volcanic activity, not C02. The very famous schematic you've seen depicting drastically warmer temperatures during the Medieval Warm Period was sketched by a climate scientist by the name of Hubert Lamb and surveyed the climate only of central England and western Europe, not the entire globe. Climate deniers like to say that Mann erased the MWP "bump" in that schematic, but in fact Mann used more comprehensive data to survey the entire world. You should also be aware that Lamb's schematic ends in 1950, leaving off our very warmest decades.
