@Mountain Fisher Here are just a few of the follow-up studies that support Michael Mann's hockey stick data. There exists an entire hockey team of data, which, apparently, you are unaware:
PAGES 2k Consortium. 2013. Continental-scale Temperature Variability During the Past Two Millennia. Nature Geoscience 6:339-346: Used multiple proxies (tree rings, sediment cores, ice cores, stalagmites, pollen, etc) to reconstruct regional and global temperatures since AD 1. The study involved 79 scientists from around the world.Marcott, S. A., J. D. Shakun, P. U. Clark, and A. C. Mix. 2013. A Reconstruction of Regional and Global Temperature for the Past 11,300 Years. Science 339:1198-1201: Reconstructed global temperatures over the past 11,000 years using sediment cores.  Data ended at AD 1940.Crowley, T. J. 2000. Causes of Climate Change Over the Past 1000 Years. Science 289:270-277: Used both his own and Mann et al. (1999)'s hockey sticks to examine the cause of temperature changes over the past 1,000 years.  Found that natural forcings could not explain twentieth century warming without the effect of greenhouse gases.Wahl, E. R. and C. M. Ammann. 2007. Robustness of the Mann, Bradley, Hughes Reconstruction of Northern Hemisphere Surface Temperatures: Examination of Criticisms Based on the Nature and Processing of Proxy Climate Evidence. Climatic Change 85:33-69: Used the tree ring proxies, glacial proxies, and borehole proxies used by Mann et al. (1998, 1999) to recalculate Northern Hemisphere temperatures since AD 800.  Refuted the McIntyre and McKitrick criticisms and showed that those criticisms were based on flawed statistical techniques.Huang, S, H. N. Pollack, and P. Shen. 2000. Temperature Trends over the past five centuries reconstructed from borehole temperatures. Nature 403:756-758: Reconstructed global average temperatures since AD 1500 using temperature data from 616 boreholes from around the globe.Bertrand, C., M. Loutre, M. Crucifix, and A. Berger. 2002. Climate of the Last Millenium: A Sensitivity Study. Tellus 54A:221-244.: Reconstructed solar output, volcanic activity, land use changes, and greenhouse gas concentrations since AD 1000, then computed the expected temperature changes due to those forcings.  Compared the computed temperature changes with two independent temperature reconstructions.Esper, J., E. R. Cook, and F. H. Schweingruber. 2002. Low-frequency Signals in Long Tree-ring Chronologies for Reconstructing Past Temperature Variability. Science 295:2250-2253: Reconstructed Northern Hemisphere temperatures between AD 800 and AD 2000 using tree ring chronologies.Cronin, T. M., G. S. Dwyer, T. Kamiya, S. Schwede, and D. A. Willard. 2003. Medieval Warm Period, Little Ice Age and 20th Century Temperature Variability from Chesapeake Bay. Global and Planetary Change 36: 17-29: Reconstructed temperatures between 200 BC and AD 2000 around Chesapeake Bay, USA, using sediment core records.Pollack, H. N. and J. E. Smerdon. 2004. Borehole Climate Reconstructions: Spatial Structure and Hemispheric Averages. Journal of Geophysical Research 109:D11106: Hegerl, G. C., T. J. Crowley, M. Allen, W. T. Hyde, H. N. Pollack, J. Smerdon, and E. Zorita. 2007. Detection of Human Influence on a New, Validated 1500-year Temperature Reconstruction. Journal of Climate 20:650-666: Combined borehole temperatures and tree ring proxies to reconstruct Northern Hemisphere temperatures over the past 1,450 years.  Introduced a new calibration technique between proxy temperatures and instrumental Reconstructed global average temperatures since AD 1500 using temperature data from 695 boreholes from around the globe.Esper, J., R. J. S. Wilson, D. C. Frank, A. Moberg, H. Wanner, and J. Luterbacher. 2005. Climate: Past Ranges and Future Changes. Quarternary Science Reviews 24:2164-2166: Compared and averaged five independent reconstructions of Northern Hemisphere temperatures from AD 1000 to AD 2000.Moberg, A., D. M. Sonechkin, K. Holmgren, N. M. Datsenko, and W. Karlen. 2005. Highly Variable Northern Hemisphere Temperatures Reconstructed from Low- and High-resolution Proxy Data. Nature 433:613-617: Combined tree ring proxies with glacial ice cores, stalagmite, and lake sediment proxies to reconstruct Northern Hemisphere temperatures from AD 1 to AD 2000.Oerlemans, J. 2005. Extracting a Climate Signal from 169 Glacier Records. Science 308:675-677: Reconstructed global temperatures from AD 1500 to AD 2000 using 169 glacial ice proxies from around the globe.Rutherford, S., M. E. Mann, T. J. Osborn, R. S. Bradley, K. R. Briffa, M. K. Hughes, and P. D. Jones. 2005. Proxy-based Northern Hemisphere Surface Temperature Reconstructions: Sensitivity to Method, Predictor Network, Target Season, and Target Domain. Journal of Climate 18:2308-2329: Compared two multi-proxy temperature reconstructions and tested the results of each reconstruction for sensitivity to type of statistics used, proxy characteristics, seasonal variation, and geographic location.  Concluded that the reconstructions were robust to various sources of error.
D'Arrigo, R. R. Wilson, and G. Jacoby. 2006. On the Long-term Context for Late Twentieth Century Warming. Journal of Geophysical Research 111:D03103: Reconstructed Northern Hemisphere temperatures between AD 700 and AD 2000 from multiple tree ring proxies using a new statistical technique called Regional Curve Standardization.  Concluded that their new technique was superior to the older technique used by previous reconstructions.Osborn, T. J. and K. R. Briffa. 2006. The Spatial Extent of 20th-century Warmth in the Context of the Past 1200 Years. Science 841-844: Used 14 regional temperature reconstructions between AD 800 and AD 2000 to compare spatial extent of changes in Northern Hemisphere temperatures.  Found that twentieth century warming was more widespread than any other temperature change of the past 1,200 years.Juckes, M. N., M. R. Allen, K. R. Briffa, J. Esper, G. C. Hegerl, A. Moberg, T. J. Osborn, and S. L. Weber. 2007. Millenial Temperature Reconstruction Intercomparison and Evaluation. Climate of the Past 3:591-609: Combined multiple older reconstructions into a meta-analysis.  Also used existing proxies to calculate a new Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction.Wahl, E. R. and C. M. Ammann. 2007. Robustness of the Mann, Bradley, Hughes Reconstruction of Northern Hemisphere Surface Temperatures: Examination of Criticisms Based on the Nature and Processing of Proxy Climate Evidence. Climatic Change 85:33-69: Used the tree ring proxies, glacial proxies, and borehole proxies used by Mann et al. (1998, 1999) to recalculate Northern Hemisphere temperatures since AD 800.  Refuted the McIntyre and McKitrick criticisms and showed that those criticisms were based on flawed statistical techniques.Wilson, R., R. D'Arrigo, B. Buckley, U. Büntgen, J. Esper, D. Frank, B. Luckman, S. Payette, R. Vose, and D. Youngblut. 2007. A Matter of Divergence: Tracking Recent Warming at Hemispheric Scales Using Tree Ring Data. Journal of Geophysical Research 112:D17103: Reconstructed Northern Hemisphere temperatures from AD 1750 to AD 2000 using tree ring proxies that did not show a divergence problem after AD 1960.

So, a issue with this from a conservative perspective is the tradeoffs.  Most rational conservatives agree that releasing additional carbon into the atmosphere will change the climate.  However there are two issues with us accepting most "climate action" the first is the net effect of rising temperatures, this will have negative effects on some regions and positive effects on other regions, though I'm willing to accept that the overall effect will probably be negative.  The real disagreement is on the effect of the typically proposed actions.  We would ask if we spend X$ trillion on program Y how much will that effect the climate in 50-100 years?  Would it make more sense to spend X$ on increasing our national productivity instead, with the idea being that our increased productivity will allow us to deal with the effects of climate change?  That's what you need to show if you want support from conservatives, that you're program is worth the cost.  We've seen this kind of situation before, with people convinced that we needed to limit population to prevent mass starvation.  That was solved with technology, artificial fertilizer and contraceptives.

Have increased CO2 levels helped farmers in the production of food products by promoting plant growth?

Yes, but high C02 also depletes some staple crops, especially rice, of their zinc, iron and protein content. Some plants lose part of their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. i would like to say, as a libertarian, that my political position has nothing to do with denying climate change.  there are some large think tanks that claim to be libertarian as a cover for regressive ideas, just like there are republican racists and democratic quasi communists.  the real libertarian argument is that bureaucratic mandates cannot possibly address such a complex technological issue, which is constantly evolving.  so what can?  as the narrator above says, investors are migrating from petro investments to renewable companies, which stimulates financial incentives for innovation.  another point worth considering is that, although the human cause of climate change [and pollution] has been known for decades, even to the oil companies, renewable technologies that were capable of providing realistic alternatives haven't existed until fairly recently, and even today they're not good enough to replace the petrochemical sector entirely.  but that gap is closing quickly, due to market forces and the steady march of science.  it would be nice if politicians creating a Green New Deal could make this evolution happen much faster, but libertarians think this is extremely unlikely compared to letting the market do its thing without interference.  the Carter administration would have done so if they could, but back in those days the technology just didn't exist, and we weren't even close.  at least Carter, as a physicist, understood the difference between the grandiose policies of bureaucrats and the reality of physical limitations.  also, moderate or lefty libertarians like myself cannot understand the deliberate lies of climate change deniers, because they don't get to move to another planet if things get unpleasant here.  but at the same time we see a lot of hypocrisy, as we have seen with governors and mayors imposing lockdowns and mask mandates last year; restrictive policies are good for the masses, but many politicians who issue this orders are caught violating them.  likewise, Al Gore and Richard Branson put huge amounts of effort into climate activism, and yet i don't really think they deny themselves any first-world comforts in life.  everyone has excuses for why their own resource consumption is justifiable, but they preach austerity to others.  that's just human nature, and we should be aware of that when listening to our leaders.

@Sigi Don't get too defensive.  

You do not appear to be cognizant of the treaty process as it works in the USA.  From the very beginning, after humiliating King Georges forces, our founders were very much opposed to "foreign entanglements"

The treaty process works like this in the USA:  the executive branch engages and negotiates with other countries in pursuit of some perceived mutual benefit.   (Keep this in mind, as a nation we are not to be "friendly" with other nations, or at least that was the goal, anymore than you or I would call our banker a "friend.")
   
After some agreed upon terms have been documented and signed by the Executive, the instrument is brought before the US Senate who is, or at  least was, supposed to serve as a watchdog over an errant Executive with equal representation in this oversight by all 50 states.  There the proposed treaty is examined to make certain the proposal is not unwholesome to the many states individual interests as well as to the federal apparatus as a whole.

After lengthy debate allowing each state to air its concerns the document is put to a vote requiring 67 of 100 Senators to indicate Aye.   The Treaty is then documented in formal legislation.  Its about as easy to ratify a treaty in the USA as it is to amend our constitution, the last time that occurred, was 42 years ago.   

Thus the Kyoto protocol proudly brought back by the Clinton regime went down with 1 aye to 99 nays in the Senate.   (there is always one idiot) .   

Obama did not even dare drag his Paris Agreement document in front of the Senate.

Such un-ratified agreements carry the same weight as a carnival barker's guarantee.  The senescent and enfeebled petty swindler Biden's signature carries the same weight - zero.  

Thus we never broke either of these worthless treaties since we were never a party to them.   This makes us completely trustworthy and unlike most of the signatory nations whose actions in screwing their own populations have gone largely ignored since claiming partyship to the agreements.     

Australia, China, and Germany share this in common, their "demon coal" per capita consumption of coal is not only far larger than that of the USA but  continues to rise at a rapid rate while ours as a non-signatory have plunged with each passing year.

I hope this clears the fog between your ears.

@Cani Terrae The problem with climate models is that there is so much of the formula that is nothing but guess work. In order to get the numbers they have to "GUESS" at how sensitive the atmosphere is to co2 change. ANY model that says the sensitivity is less than 3°c per doubling of co2, can not predict any disaster in the future. ANY model that has a sensitivity of more than 1°c per doubling of co2 can not predict the current state beginning at the end of the last century.

In other words, IF the sensitivity is high enough to predict a disaster of anything worthy of our spending so much money, it can not track accurately the changes in temperature of the last 100 years. Any  model that can track anything CLOSE to the reality of the last century, says there is no reason to spend any money on the climate because we can not affect it and there is no risk to anyone.

Anthropogenic climate change is complete nonsense. 

Carbon dioxide is trace levels in your atmosphere at 400 ppm.

History even records climate change... we all have seen climate change from 
the three major Ice-ages recorded in history to the subsequent warming 
periods (which were the Medieval warming period in the Roman warming period).

has nothing to do with creating global warming. CO2 Is currently 400 ppm. 
That is one carbon-dioxide molecule for every 2500 parts of the atmosphere.

CO2 only holds heat for a few seconds and there is not enough to drive climate- it is thermodynamically impossible and yet we are told it is true. *PERVECTION* is the important new word that everyone on planet Earth should understand.  “Pervection” is the mechanism that makes a Newton’s Cradle toy work, and is defined as "through mass mechanical energy transmission."   The vastly underappreciated phenomenon of pervection destroys the validity of current doomsday climate change theology

Solar heating of the Earth’s surface causes surface level air to warm, but that warmth is automatically carried to the stratosphere through both convection cooling and by an even more powerful force: pervection cooling.  Imagine our atmosphere filled with a variety of gases, and each molecule of gas as a little ball.  How are you going to stop all those little floating balls from banging into one another and transmitting their kinetic energy up to the stratosphere?  *Without a solid glass or plastic wall surrounding the Earth there can be no greenhouse effect.*  The modest infrared absorptive properties of carbon dioxide and methane only makes pervection cooling and convection cooling work more efficiently, so the net result is nothing.  

Carbon dioxide is a tiny odorless, nontoxic trace gas that makes up just .04% of our atmosphere.  Atmospheric carbon dioxide creates and fuels all life on Earth, and is the true molecular STAFF OF LIFE.  We create, transport, and store all of our food with the absolutely essential help of oil and natural gas.  *No fossil fuels means no food!*  

For scientific details, please watch  *Balloons in the Air: Understanding Weather and Climate* on YouTube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XfRBr7PEawY

When I look at the global temperature as derived indepently by various different international research groups, they seem to agree very well with each other: http://berkeleyearth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2019_Comparison-768x433.png
So I would really like to see the alternative "historical temperature data" that you believe is an honest representation of global temperature since about 1900.

Also note that historical temperature records are by far not the only source we have. Most recently there are satellite measurements, and to go further back into the past, scientists look at tree ring data and sediments in oceans and lakes from all over the world.
I don't dispute that temperature fluctuates a lot from year to year and from place to place, but when scientists reconstruct the (smoothed) global temperature over the last 20000 years (going back to the coldest time of the last glaciation or "ice age"), this is what they find: https://i.imgur.com/z3T6RTE.jpg

It is a popular delusion that mans’ effects on the earth’s climate are significant and dangerous. A modest amount of warming has the net beneficial effects of increased agricultural yields, reduced winter heating costs and fewer deaths from hypothermia.
Astrophysicists have recently opined that an ideal planet would have a mean surface temperature 5 degrees centigrade higher than the current earth mean surface temperature of 15 degrees centigrade.
Spending trillions of dollars trying to prevent beneficial change is lunacy.
It is also important for people to understand that the earth cannot act as its own experimental control. Computer models of complex phenomena are subject to the biases of the modellers and amplify errors over time. The term “climate denier” is disingenuous.

@nathan: 5 percent of the atmosphere by volume of methane is approximately 140 trillion tons. It’s molecular weight is barely over 50 percent of the atmospheric mean, so it would drift to the upper atmosphere.
My estimate for atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration in 2041 is 455 parts per million.
Any warming would mainly affect regions above the 60th parallels.
Sea level rise is the main adverse effect of warming. It is currently rising at 3mm per annum or 3 meters per thousand years.
Arrhenius opined that increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations had the beneficial effects of increased agricultural yields and postponing the next glacial maximum. He initially estimated that the climate sensitivity to atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration was a 5 degree centigrade temperature increase per doubling of concentration. He subsequently revised his estimate down to 2 degrees. 1 degree is likely the real figure due to negative feedback from increased atmospheric convection and increased cloud cover.
As COVID 19  graphically demonstrates ,there are more important issues than climate change. Preventing war and eliminating poverty are also much more important.

For reference, 415ppm of CO2, that was the climate during the Pliociene (5.3-2.6 mya). Trees growing near the North and South Poles, 50-60 ft more rise in sea levels than today, and global temperatures 3C-4C warmer. At the end of the Permian, 251m years ago, global temperatures rose by six degrees, 95% of species were wiped out. 

You don't need a computer to track CO2 in atmosphere.  A scientific calculator is sufficient to predict CO2 levels using the following formula:  
280 × (1 + e^ (0.0222 × (year-2052))) 
which for the year 2020, it reduces to 280 × (1 + e (0.0222 × (-32))) = 280 × (1 + e -0.7104) = 280 × ( 1 + 0.491447579 ) = 417.605.  
That's consistent with the May 2020 record high of 417 parts per million (ppm) carbon dioxide as measured at the Mauna Loa Observatory, which has continually measured CO2 in the atmosphere since 1958. Temperatures will eventually follow exponential rates of atmospheric CO2.  


It’s much harder to predict future global average temperatures except to note that it will eventually increase with anthropogenic increases of CO2.  At some point, temperatures will have a separate exponential curve for a short period when permafrost releases large amounts of methane.  This could happen as soon as 2030.  That’s because warming oceans release pent-up methane from the sea bed, and it’s flammable. This video is typical of the straw man arguments I often hear. Goodness gracious me, nobody denies that the climate is changing. It is always changing. For most of the present interglacial (the 10,000 years of the Holocene epoch) the climate has been warmer than today. Now it is cooler than 5,000 years ago. It is cooler now than during the Roman optimum or the medieval warm period. That's climate change. It exists. The climate has been warming for the past 200 years. That's a good thing because it was quite cold during the Dalton minimum. Nobody denies that the level of atmospheric carbon dioxide is growing, but it is still lower than it has been for most of the last 10,000 years. However, over the last fifty years the level of atmospheric CO2 has shot up at an unusually rapid rate. Almost nobody denies that this is as a result of massive industrialisation over the last century. However, while there has been a rapid increase in CO2 levels, there has not been a corresponding increase in temperature. Over the past 20 years, while CO2 levels have continued to climb, atmospheric temperatures have not, they have levelled. The IPCC predicted that the temperature would increase because of the increased CO2, but this has not occurred. Not only have temperatures not risen in accordance with the IPCC's worst case prediction, they haven't even increased in accordance with their best case prediction. The above document implies it a FACT that there is a link between fossil fuels and temperature increase, but this has not been borne out by the climate record. It is therefore not a fact. The evidence is not supporting the IPCC predictions. In accordance with Newtonian principals, the IPCC should acknowledge their theory is not on the money. They should not remain silent when others ignore the evidence. Albert Einstein once jokingly said: 'When the evidence doesn't support your theory, change the evidence.'  But is the world doing just that? It seems some people are still promoting the theory of CO2-based, man-made climate change, saying it is real, despite the fact that the evidence over the last two decades indicates it is not. I think it would be better to accept the bleeding obvious, that the climate is boss. We don't control the climate. We are not gods.

Earth's climate changes over hundreds of thousands, or millions of years. Humans have had thermometers for about 500 years, and have been keeping track of global temperatures (with questionable accuracy) for less than 150 years. Practically every climate model they have made has been wrong. We are sitting on 50 years of wrong climate predictions. Humans might be contributing to the climate, I don't deny that. What I do deny is that we are headed to an absolute apocalypse if we don't shut down the world economy, today. There is a reason climate scientists aren't generally "climate activists". It is predicted that in about 10,000 years there will be another ice age, regardless of "carbon emissions", it is due to the Earth's orbit around the sun. The system is dynamic and has been going through cycles since long before humanity. The predictions have almost always been wrong, because they believe it has one underlying cause, and ignores the huge list of things that contribute to the climate.

Here is some math.  Nitrogen 78% of the atmosphere. Oxygen 21% of the atmosphere.  That's 99% so far.  Of the remaining 1% .04% (remember of 1%) is CO2.  Of that .04% of 1%, 97% is naturally occurring. So 3% of .04% of 1% is man made CO2.  That's a really small amount.  Like kenXsolo said.  Follow the money.
Yes and that 3% of 0.4% is still much

Yes, the relative magnitude of anthropogenic sources of CO2 is small. However, you are missing the point:
Before the industrial revolution, the sources and sinks of atmospheric CO2 were roughly in balance, meaning that there was no significant change in atmospheric concentration. But adding anthropogenic sources which were not balanced by an increase of the sinks created an imbalance! Thus, there is an accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere and an increase over time! THIS is the problem!

Quick example, wrong numbers: let's assume anthropogenic source are only 1% of the total CO2 source (your number), but they are not compensated by an increase of the CO2 sinks (in reality, 50% of these extra emissions are compensated). Let's assume that the sources and sinks don't vary over time. 1% doesn't look like much, but after 100 yrs it would correspond to the total annual emissions of CO2 (natural + anthropo) staying in the atmosphere! In this quick example, it corresponds to ~30% increase of the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere...
https://jancovici.com/en/climate-change/ghg-and-carbon-cycle/wont-the-carbon-sinks-absorb-the-extra-co2/

In short: You should be concerned about CUMULATIVE emissions, not relative fluxes!

What is the cause of climate change and how can it be solved?
Many people think that the cause of climate change is carbon dioxide, and reducing carbon dioxide can prevent climate change.
This is a bit convincing, but not correct.
The exact cause of climate change is "thermal excess" on the earth.
Therefore, to stop climate change, we must focus on stopping of the "thermal excess".

"GREEN NEW DEAL" has good intentions. However, there are several problems. 
The biggest problem is that it is less economical. It means that it is difficult for many people to actively participate. 
Therefore, coercion must be mobilized to achieve the desired goal, and excessive coercion hinders the achievement of the goal. 
This is a fundamental problem.
Also, waste is another problem. 
Waste solar cells and waste blades are discharged, and the waste batteries of ESS adversely affect the environment.

Although there is a problem with the need for large land, the best way to reduce heat and carbon dioxide is to create big forests.
Trump should publicize the effects of "One trillion trees" to others and urge the world to join in and work together.

Why is "One trillion trees" so effective?
First of all, it is economical. Compared to solar power generation and wind power generation, it does not require a lot of funds at the beginning. 
forests has a long lifespan, and does not require additional facilities such as ESS and power transmission and distribution facilities, and does not emit waste.

In addition, One trillion trees absorb enormous amounts of solar heat.
Photosynthesis requires infrared rays from the sun.
It absorbs infrared rays (heat rays) and ultraviolet rays to perform photosynthesis, turning carbon dioxide into oxygen and making glucose.
One trillion trees absorbing solar heat is very good at slowing down climate change. 
The reason people don't really care about trees absorbing heat is that they don't think the cause of global warming is fundamentally "overheating," but rather carbon dioxide.

Well duh, we've known that for decades now, that's not news, that's high school biology.

But despite that fact, agricultural productivity per acre is up 30% in the last 40 years.

Also, evapotranspiration accounts for 60-70% of all rainfall on Earth, with it being 40% or less in wet areas, and up to 100% in deserts. Meaning when you increase evapotranspiration you increase inland rainfall, especially if you increase other forms of evaporation. This is in large part why the Sahara became vegetated during the Holocene climate optimum, rising temperatures caused increased rainfall along coast and mountain fronts and increased transpiration, which allowed moisture to go further inland.

@Alltoc ? I think you are confused. The Price per BBL didn't become negative.  The Futures price per bbl became negative.  The price per bbl is the price for a barrel of oil. The thing that went negative was the Futures price per bbl.  These are not the same.  

Oil is sold in lots and is used as a security for companies to borrow again.

For example, Exxon says "I have 3 billion barrels of oil proven in such and such a location. I can drill them for $X and I can sell them for $Y at $Z profit. So, Mr Chase Bank, I would like to borrow $1.5 Billion to fund my operation.  You can use the oil in place as collateral for my loan"  (the oil in the ground is basically like a house you borrow money to buy, if you fail to pay the bank gets it).

Mr Chase bank says okay, and Exxon drills.

Now Mr Chase bank doesn't really want to sit around with a paper note in his bank instead of money. So Mr Chase Bank sells the "FUTURES" contract of Exxon to Joe Schmoe.  Joe Schmoe gives Mr Chase $1.7 Billion  and Mr Chase gives Joe schmoe the right to be repaid by Exxon over the course of the drilling and production.

What happened is, suddenly supply of oil from saudi and russia went up, the direct market devalued the $/bbl, and so all of the borrowing up above which was based on a predicted $Y price per bbl are now wrong.  Now Exxon can't even get a profit much less a return to Joe Schmoe, so Joe Schmoe's Futures contract is worth NEGATIVE $.

The Price per BBL of oil didn't go negative, the Future's Price per BBL of oil went negative.  This is to say, that the supply exceeded demand SO much that there is no incentive to fund future drilling operations (for a while anyway).  OR you can think of it this way, there was SO much oil on the market, that oil companies were PAYING storage facilities to take it.  Even though the price per bbl is still positive, the value to the company for producing it is negative.

The “natural combustion cycle” has a cooling effect on the planet. An example is forest fires put smoke and ash into the sky and every snowflake has, at its heart, a nucleus of an airborne solid more commonly referred to as an aerosol. The Greenhouse effect of 34C is calculated using a simple equation using Bond Albedo, Emissivity and the result is compared to the surface temperature.

First the Albedo of the Earth is calculated including the clouds and the emissivity is based on the surface. So which is it? Somewhere up in the air or at the surface? If the answer is in the sky then the emissivity is not "approximately 1.0", it is lower as clouds have low emissivity compared to the surface.

Secondly most heat leaves Earth from the atmosphere after being transported upwards by convection and evaporation so perhaps that is where the we would find the "correct" temperature. For every km up we go the average temperature falls by 6.1 degrees so just above the main clouds the GH effect has dropped by 18 degrees

Add in the effect of lower emissivity and it drops again. It is a certainty that the GH effect is not 34 and it is probable that it is in the bottom third of that range.

So that's two thirds of the GH effect gone just by thinking about the first equation in the theory.

Using the term 'denial' in this context doesn't make sense.  Climate change refers to a theory.  Denial is being used in the sense of someone who is refusing to accept an empirically verified prima fascia evident fact.  That's why no one who doesn't believe in the theory of evolution is referred to as a denier.  All theories are uncertain, including the anthropogenic climate change theory.  People who don't believe in the climate change theory are simply people who are not convinced by the evidence proponents have presented to support it.

@Cani Terrae 
Eh, it's been relatively linear the past 20 years, rising 3.1 mm per year, and over the past 100 years, sea level has risen on average about 2.1mm per year, though it rose as fast as 3.5mm per year between 1930 and 1950.

It is relatively difficult to say how sea levels will change into the future because this depends on future melt rates, sea surface temperatures, and deep-sea temperatures, so it is best to base the future off current trends as well as the past.

With that said, yes, vast swaths of those two states will be underwater, though in Florida's case 30-60% of this is due to land subsidence and in Louisiana's case 90% of this land loss is due to land subsidence New Orleans, for example, is sinking at a rate of 5 meters per century, compared to sea levels which are currently rising at a rate of 0.35 to 0.3 meters per century, other Gulf Coast cities such as Houston, Galveston, Baton Rouge, Corpus Christi etc. are sinking at similar rates. 

If anything these cities should be focusing 90% of their resources for fighting sea-level rise towards fighting land subsidence and restoring aquifer systems beneath these cities.

In Florida's case, cities like Miami are sinking at about the same rate as sea levels are rising.

Now, Sea level rise is the most severe in Central California, with cities like Sacramento (the house I used to live in was at sea level, the park next to it was three feet below sea level) being one of the most threatened by sea-level rise and rainfall flooding in the world, though again, this is largely because the area is sinking, parts of the central valley are sinking at a staggering rate of 2 inches per MONTH. Meaning again, the primary issue facing these areas with regards to sea level rise isn't rising sea but rather sinking land, and that is where the majority of resources should be directed to.

I have absolutely no doubt that the Oil companies are funding groups to block climate change legislation. But this article has some serious deceptivet practices in it.

The biggest example is quoting total revenue when they are talking about percentage invested in something. Revenue is important to a company - you can't make a profit without it. But you could have annual revenue in the trillions and still make a loss. But of course, it's great to say "Chevron's revenue was $200 BILLION". 

Ongoing research, investment in new products etc comes from pre-tax profit - not revenue. Chevron, in 2019, had pretax profit of about $5B on $140B revenue. Now 5 Billion profit is still a lot of money - but it's about 1/30th of their revenue. So an investment which is "only 0.23% of revenue" is actually 8% of profit. 

Come on CNBC - if you can't make your case fairly and honestly, don't bother trying. Treat your audience with some respect: otherwise you are just as bad as the lobbyists (pro and anti) you just interviewed.

@Jimme FZ A law isn't the "highest standard in science", wtf are you talking about?  A law is almost universally a statement of a simple (often mathematical), almost always empirical in origin, relationship WITHIN a discipline of science.  Theories explain laws, not the other way around.  And it's why "laws" are generally only "accurate" given certain conditions.

Newton's laws, for example, are "accurate" if you've got the condition of "non-relativistic".  Ohm's law is "accurate" for small electric fields but just about any material will have Ohm's law break down at a certain point.

Rayleigh Jean's law breaking down was what gave us Planck's Law.  I mean, I could keep going, but I think you grasp the point.  Laws are by no means the "highest standard" in science.

Who told you otherwise?

@Killua2001 A Law, the highest standard in science, was corrected, that is the point. and If you didn't know that Relativity is subject to many debates then you have no idea what your talking about. science doesn't belong in an echo chamber and disagreement is essential.

Saying 'newtons law' is up for debate is as idiotic as saying the shape of the earth is still 'up for debate'.  Relativity only "upstaged" it by correcting it *at the margins*.

Likewise, "climate change" is based on some pretty god damn simple basic thermodynamics.   We're capturing a lot more energy than we used to put out. Yeah, there are disagreements as to exactly the degree of forcings humans contribute.  How fast feedbacks happen.  Etc.  There are always debates at the margins.

But as Isaac Asimov put it in his "Relativity of Wrong", "when people thought the earth was flat, they were wrong. When people thought the earth was spherical, they were wrong. Good news: no scientist is claiming that we'll all die in 10 years or 40 years. We're a resourceful species and there are nearly 8 billion of us! Even when tens of millions of people become climate refugees and say a fifth of them die, that's comparatively a drop in the bucket. _However_, every additional ton of CO2 we put in the atmosphere will over the next CENTURIES increase the warming of the Earth, adding to the ongoing warming from the 500 billion or so tons we've already added. So every year we don't reduce greenhouse gas emissions makes the likely warming by 2100 worse. Hence the accepted projection that if we don't reduce fossil fuel emissions dramatically over the next few decades, we are committed to 2° C or more warming by 2100 (and even more warming in the centuries thereafter), and the cumulative effects of that much warming will be catastrophic overall. Does that help you understand the timetable?

The Earth had been slowly warming since the last glaciation some 18,000 years ago, and in the distant past the climate has regularly cooled to ice age conditions. In the 1970s a few climatologists, certainly not majority, thought there were signs that the switch to "a new ice age" was within centuries, and they got a lot of press. However, since then the fossil fuels we've burned have completely overwhelmed any possible cooling trend, and instead caused about 0.9° C of warming! We've delayed the onset of the next ice age by 100,000 years or more, and if temperatures continue to rise at 0.15°C per decade,  large regions of the Earth will instead be uninhabitable within centuries.

     In an online lesson* on Acceleration, the graphs showing Distance vs. Time can be applied to “sea level rise” of oceanography. But also Speed vs. Distance is another acceleration form. Two forms, but most people only think there’s one kind of acceleration.
     Climate alarmists confuse two things: velocity speed vs distance speed (over same period of time). 
These two graphs show the difference*
     Sea levels always ebb and flow between ice ages, when the polar regions increase or decrease in size. But the way to know if it’s natural or manmade is seeing if the sea level graphs go from straight and steady, to curved and increasing... Do they?
The NOAA sea level graphs are all straight and steady all over the world for the last 150 years. Half that time (recent most industrial 75 years) should show an upward-curving (not still straight) graph, as fossil fuels emitted more CO2 — if the Earth couldn’t absorb it naturally.
     But, as NOAA’s own graphs show, they do not increase in sea level speed (height distance over time). Alarmists wrongly interpret steady acceleration graphs since 150 years ago, but think it’s increasing speed in sea level height. It’s not, because the sea level graphs are straight, even in places where sea levels are falling (e.g.: Sweden https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends_station.shtml?id=050-141 ). 
     Therefore, we can conclude the Earth is absorbing CO2 and there’s no “melting” global ice (it may evaporate from sublimation** instead). The CO2 greenhouse theory from 100 years ago was refuted soon after by another scientist. H2O vapor in the atmosphere totally cancels out greenhouse effects of CO2 and methane emissions overwhelmingly. 

* FAQ: “but why is street flooding worse along beaches and rivers?”
A: local and regional water management planning and local sinking ground from subsidence ***
* FAQ: “but why do I see global temperatures rising and it’s so hot in Australia in December?”
A: actual thermometer records show it was hotter many times before now, when CO2 levels and fossil fuel use was lower; plus the alarmists altered the historic records in their fake science research and press releases. The seasons are opposite in southern vs. northern hemisphere.

Of course climate change is real.  We've known this since the late '70s.  Here's a picture of Gordon MacDonald showing us how high the ocean would be by 2030 (https://skeptics.stackexchange.com/questions/42192/did-climate-scientists-in-the-1980s-predict-a-1-meter-sea-level-rise-by-now) and we're well on our way to that being true.
We as a species have allowed and encouraged *corporations* to use industrial technology to pollute the globe.  And every breathing one of us exhales tonnes of carbon dioxide, and the plants we depend on for food and oxygen in turn depend on carbon dioxide *which is not a "pollutant."*
How do we responsibly answer the threat of CO2 levels? First, we establish that is IS a threat. Sherwood Idso's research (https://res.cloudinary.com/highereducation/image/upload/w_740,h_541,c_scale,f_auto,fl_lossy,q_auto/v1/TheBestSchools.org/Figure-16) suggests it is not. Additionally, CO2 concentrations aboard US submarines (which stay submerged for six months at a time) *average* 4000ppm, and get as high as 8000ppm; ten to twenty times the current concentrations. Plants respond better to increased CO2. If you've never seen it, just fly over the Netherlands at night and notice the swaths of greenhouses that flood the winter sky with light. In addition to light, *they keep the CO2 levels extremely high* so the tulips can be bloomed in time to be harvested and transported to New York in time for the first day of spring. (You can also search "Netherlands greenhouses night" and find images.)
We might also track the levels of the oceans to see if there's an effect there. NOAA data from 375 long-term trend tide stations is publicly available, and their changes have been linear. Have a look at one I happen to have in hand: NOAA 8628660, 960-065, PSMSL 399 at Portsmouth, Virginia (http://sealevel.info/MSL_graph.php?id=8638660). The net change across that station has been *linear* for most of a century since it started; about 3mm per year. The thickness of 24 sheets of paper in your printer.
Now look at Neah Bay, Washington (http://sealevel.info/MSL_graph.php?id=9443090) It has also moved about 150mm in 50 years, but it went *down.*
Or look at Port Angeles, Washington, where it has risen less than one millimeter in 40 years.
Keep clicking that blue triangle to flip through other stations; that green line in all of them is CO2. Note the sea level vector is wholly unaffected by CO2 rise.
If sea levels have been rising for at least 40 years, why doesn't Venice already have two stories underwater?  Have they been jacking it up every year to keep pace?  Why isn't DisneyWorld a port on the Florida coast?  Remember, tides change as the earth spins under the gravitational influences of the moon and sun. In the Bay of Fundy (Canada,) the difference is 50 feet between high tide and low tide, and it has nothing to do with "global warming," but it makes for a nice tourist attraction.  http://bayoffundytourism.com/worlds-highest-tides/
Facts are important, and here's one:  "Where there is a trough, there will be pigs."  (Alex Pushkin)  Teachers who want tenure have to toe the line.  It has become - at the very least - politically expedient to say one believes in global warming...
oops, I mean "climate change."  Change is endemic with a complex atmosphere/biosphere like that of Earth.  I've put 110K km on my Nissan Leaf all-electric car over the past decade because if we burn up all our petrochemicals, what are we going to get the plastics out of which our world is made?  And as a bonus, it puts a *hard stop* on my dependence upon religious lunatics' sweet crude.

@mwstar Sounds like a get-rich-quick claim to me.  Have you studied the claim in detail?  It is based on actual facts, or just a bunch of cherry-picked data points?   Is it logically sound, with each step well established as a reliable cause-and-effect?
I'm one of the biggest proponents of accelerating change.  (Example: We used to only be able to send messages as fast as feet.  Then we thought to send them at the speed of horses' feet.  Then at the speed of a motorised carriage, and finally at the speed of jets.)  And suddenly...email.  
Change of the climate, specifically the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, only happens so fast.  The amount of it our industrial tech adds is a tiny fraction (between 1 and 2%, I think) of the total output of every carbon-dioxide-exhaling critter on the planet (this includes you.)
It has been fantastically higher in the past.  It makes plants grow better and helps green our world.  The idea of a runaway carbon dioxide level doesn't obtain because...chemistry.  Rising carbon dioxide levels don't make the growth *rate* increase any more than pressing the accelerator of your car will take you to light speed if you don't keep from pressing the pedal too hard.  If that worked, chemistry would be very different.
By all means, champion environmental responsibility where you can.  But there are too many things out of your control that have far more influence than you.
India and China, for example. have *way* more people, and their own governments.  The quadrillions of tonnes of biomass pumps out more carbon dioxide in a day than all our industries do in a month.  As they say, "we are not driving this bus."

Trees and brush do not fare well in climates that are desert like for 9 months out of a year.

Increased CO2 levels aid the growth of and health of all vegetation found in semi-arid deserts.   The reason this occurs is that they are both fed and kept soil watered by CO2.   Plants lose about 100 water molecules for every CO2 molecule they ingest through their stomata. It's not my bar chart, and I don't completely subscribe to the 1° for every doubling of CO2 because it's a chaotic system and there are a lot of factors and even things CO2 affects may result in cooling instead of heating, however, if we use the 1° concept, from 400 ppm to 800 ppm is 1°, from 800 ppm to 1600 ppm is another 1°, and from 1600 to 3200 is another 1°; 1 + 1 + 1 = 3. @Chavez Harding, I think you assume a lot.  There are many hypothesis regarding CO2 and warming, and Arrhenius was overly optimistic about how much warming his grandchildren might expect; he considered the warming good.  I observe over the last century or so, the "experts" have repeatedly alternately warned of both warming and cooling.

The page is still there, so lets try the link again, ...  https://wattsupwiththat.com/2010/03/08/the-logarithmic-effect-of-carbon-dioxide/

So my point remains, as more CO2 goes into the atmosphere, temperature is affected less and less, and we are already past the steep part of the curve and onto the flatter part.  I seriously doubt we could put enough CO2 into the atmosphere to get to 1600 ppm, so the worst case would be doubling twice or 2 degrees.  As I pointed out last night, 2 degrees won't really affect Antarctica at all and the effect in the Arctic might be welcomed by those who live there.  Also, 2° is completely lost in the noise when looking at the rest of temperature fluctuation.  The graph I linked last night clearly shows temperature does not correlate with CO2 levels, so there are much larger forces than CO2 at work.  There is clearly no tipping point regarding CO2.  The NASA claim that plants are taking back ground that is more arid seems reasonable and for anyone who is truly "green" that should be the good news.

So first off, we have one of the highest rates of premature pregnancies in the developed world, which means naturally we will have more infant and maternal deaths during the birthing process and after it, because the more immature a girl is when giving birth the chances of her and her child dying increases exponentially.

The second issue really says more about how good our system (or lack thereof I suppose) is.  We have the highest standards in the world, and doctors will try to save an infant regardless of its weight and how premature it is, and if they fail to save it they count it as an infant death.

No other country on Earth does this, every other country has a weight limit, and say that if an infant is below this weight it isn't considered alive, so no attempt to save it can or will be made, and the death of the infant isn't counted.

In Russia this is about 1,000 grams, in most western country it's about 700-1000 grams, In Canada, which Is by far among the better countries when it comes to this, puts the weight at 550 grams.

@Sucker Free  Science works according to a method which is objective. Remember predictive success. The evidence and conclusions must be falsifiable. Anyone can, with their own set of evidence, present an equally falsifiable alternative or refutation. In time theories are accepted by how closely they reflect the material world, not any persons ideas. Imagine an airplane. Wrapped up in an airplane design is a whole lot of theories. As soon as that plane gets moving and flies as predicted we can tell ourselves we actually know something. The plane does not fly because theorist x,y and z claimed it would. It flies because what we think we understand actually reflects the physical world. The plane actually working is the proof. The same goes for the device you are using to view youtube. Your daily life is surrounded by products that are the result of the empirical method (science). You do not question the theories behind those things. But climate science you have decided must be wrong? Why? You clearly have no reason to since you do not understand the methodology itself nor the actual research. Science is only a method for knowing. It is nothing else. Again, it cannot, on its own tell us what we should do with knowledge or even if we should acquire certain pieces of knowledge. It can however be used to inform our ethics. The empirical method is at it's core humble. Conclusions cannot be insisted they are true without evidence external to the person doing the concluding and those conclusions can be demonstrated wrong using the same method. The method clearly works if you consider the vast increase in knowledge of the world humans have developed in only a relatively short period of time which we use to exploit that physical world to our advantage. That being said, our use of this knowledge is not without consequences as we are interacting with other natural systems. Climate science is only one area of research that is indicating a consequence of putting our knowledge to work.

@Sucker Free  Science is often about predictions. Predictive success is part of how well models/ theories are considered to be reflective of reality. If a model/ theory has problems with predictive success it does not necessarily mean the whole thing gets thrown out. It is revised so that falsifiability increases but moves towards better predictive capability. Any model from the 1890's would have been very poor for lack of data. If you mean 1980's it still would have had limited data compared to now. In many cases the predictions have actually been surpassed by reality. Be prepared for a day when you no longer play denier but instead become part of a discussion about what, if anything, we should do about it.

Even without humans the world would be warming, albeit at a slower pace - we’re still in an ice age. Earth is millions of years old, and it will be around for another million years - humans will not be, that’s evolution.

Sure, but the timescale is incredibly important. Climate changing on a scale of 1000s of years is, at least for modern humans, a non-issue - we would adapt. We would change how and where we live without even necessarily being aware of _how_ we were adapting, due to the change not being significant over a single human lifetime. It's even less of an issue now because, in a thousand years, humans will almost certainly either be extinct or space-faring. 
-
It's more significant for wildlife, but even there, the timescale is crucial - faced with the same amount in warming in 100 years or 2000, many would species would be unable to adapt in the former time frame, especially with the added strain humans are placing on the environment. 
-
Time makes all the difference.

A carbon tax, 'taking money' as you call it, has two benefits. First, it prices in the negative externalities  created by CO2 emissions. This allows other technologies, e.g. wind and solar, to compete on a level playing field in a free market economy. Letting CO2 producers dump their pollution in the atmospher is basically granting them a free subsidy that their competitors don't get, which distorts market incentives. Second, the money collected from a carbon tax can be used to fund the development of new technologies which can remediate our CO2 problem, e.g. atmospheric carbon capture or other geoengineering solutions. And for the record China should absolutely also have a carbon tax. Every nation on the planet should.

I do remember when I was in high school reading the "scholastic journal" and them saying 20 years ago that the world was doomed and that the seas would rise 200 feet in the next 10 years.  That there would be massive flooding and famine.  If we did not act NOW, to stop global warming..  Yeah.. that was 20 years ago.  Sea levels have risen less than 2 inches since then.  By looking at coastal flood plain archeology  we can see that sea levels have  risen and fallen 30+ feet in the last couple thousand years.  So sea floor levels rising and falling is nothing new.  Given the fact that the average sea level is rising by a couple milimeters a year currently, thats pretty neglegable in the grand scheme of things.  In my opinion there are much bigger fish to fry, and problems that we could actually do something about, besides the "green new deal". Global warming or Climate change is a farce and everyone knows it as they had to change its name more than once. They have changed its name since the 70s when experts stated we were returning to a new ice age. US News from 2015:

“The record-setting snowfall in New England this month — seven feet and counting in Massachusetts — poses dangerous risks through snow-covered roofs, ice dams and gutter floods.”

Fluffy, fresh snow can weigh as little as three pounds per square foot compared with 21 pounds for wet, heavy snow, according to FEMA. Ice weighs more: 57 pounds a square foot. Considering the average-size roof in the United States is in the range of 2,000 square feet, the weight of snow and ice can add up to dangerous sums.

The Boston Globe: “It’s a good idea to remove snow that's 18 inches or more on low-pitch roofs.”

Also in 1970, NASA's S.I. Rasool explained, over the next five to 10 years, there would be "such a temperature decrease [that it] could be sufficient to trigger an ice age.”

At this time, in the 70s, the media and elected officials were placing fear into mankind about a new ice age.

Of course, not a one can predict next week’s global weather in total accuracy, but they know what will occur 10 years from today.

text:
It is a scientific fact that Co2 emissions are heavier than air and therefore disperse all around us. When it is cold, Co2 vaporises. A good example of this is when a plane is flying high in a clear blue sky; we will then see a great cloud of vaporised Co2. Where clouds don't rise, but in low pressure areas they can come down as rain or snow, but they don't rise up into the stratosphere. 
Even the lightest of all bird feathers is heavier than air. And no matter wherever the wind may blow it, it will still land somewhere on the earth, or on rivers or the sea, but doesn’t go up into the stratosphere. 
Although methane, from cows, from humans and Co gas, are potential greenhouse gases, their effect is relatively short-lived. So perhaps the climate change and the global warming that spelled the end of the recognised Ice-Age, over 12,000 years ago, is also what is happening now? 
For the Sun radiates carbon among its other gases! Therefore it is more likely than not that the greenhouse effect is the carbon which is radiated from the sun! When it is waste plastic that should surely be our true concern? 
But to hit the nail firmly on the head, run your car engine on a cold morning, and then look at the end of your exhaust to see where the vaporised Co2 actually goes. You won’t need an umbrella!
